‘Please, do as I asked.’

It was the last request of a man with whom I had been making love for many days. I even thought that I loved him, although most likely I was intoxicated by the excitement of what was happening. But anyway, he died, and the only thing I could do for him was to fulfill his request.
I hesitated for a while.

I didn’t want to complicate my relationship with the Turkish police. Or rather, I didn’t want to have them at all. According to the law, it would probably be necessary to give these masks to them. Perhaps they were stolen from somewhere and they were searched for. If these are really valuable antique artifacts, I could seriously go to jail for the rest of my still quite young life.

On the other hand, I had Frank’s note with his request. At least some kind, but a document. It could have shortened my sentence by about a half… I was lost in thought. Hell, Frank was able to stress even from the afterlife.

In fact, I already knew what I would do, but to clear my conscience, I decided to wait for some sign. It’s so easy for the world and Lord Shiva to send me some clear unambiguous sign. For example, if a garbage can with two masks sticking out of it comes across on the Internet now, I will quietly throw them away…

I went down to the hall, had a snack in the buffet (out of grief I drank a can of red Coca-Cola with sugar, which in today’s cultural conditions is equivalent to a bottle of vodka from Dostoevsky) and went upstairs.
I had a new message in my mailbox. From So.
We exchanged emails in an Istanbul taxi, but I didn’t expect that she would actually write to me someday. She might not have written at all if it hadn’t been for this tragedy.

p.emphasis: Sasha!

I know about Frank. His parents thought he was still with us and called. They are terrified, of course. Aren’t you hurt? I can imagine what you’ve been through. We are in Istanbul — and we’ll be here for some time. Come here, we’ll try to comfort you.
If you want, we won’t be talking about it at all.
We’re waiting.
With love,
So and Tim

section.p: I wonder if she knew about Frank’s request for masks? And why does a person even think about these masks before death? Maybe they have an impact on the psyche?

Anyway, I was waiting for a sign — and this, of course, was it. It’s hard not to notice. But I already knew without any signs that I would do everything as Frank asked. Whatever it takes. I was just afraid I’d have to find So and Tim myself. But everything was extremely convenient.
When I checked in my luggage at the airport, I had a panic attack.
It seemed to me that the mustachioed guards were mockingly and maliciously looking in my direction, and everything that was happening in the world was a single inhuman conspiracy directed against me.

Coaches of personal growth teach that you cannot see reality in this light. But the fate of any living being, including a coach of personal growth, proves that there is simply no other way. They’ll separate you into proteins (and in the case of cremation — into atoms), and the whole world will have its share.
Sitting in the waiting area, I imagined in every detail what was going to happen.

Here are the mustachioed Janissaries and Mamelukes staring into their X-ray display, and my bag floats up to them… There are grins on their faces, they look at each other, pull it off the conveyor belt and study the tag with my name. Another poke at the keyboard, and my photo is on the monitor.
And here I am at the police station. There are masks, handcuffs and dildo on the table. An insinuating voice with a Turkish accent says:
‘Khanum, you probably already guessed why we detained your luggage…’
I shrug my shoulders.

‘We have doubts about your dildo. It is disproportionately large (“for Turkey” — the proud answer of the Slavic woman trembles in me, but at the last moment I restrain myself). In addition, the dildo is covered with silver paint with high metal content, and our scanners cannot look inside…’
Smiling haughtily, I ask:
‘And what do you want?’
An insinuating voice answers:
‘Have you ever faced a situation when you are asked to turn on your laptop at the control?’
I nod.

‘You probably guess that the control service officer is not particularly interested in your Instagram photos. The purpose of this procedure is to prove that your laptop is really a laptop, and not a bomb disguised as it.’
‘And then what?’
‘Khanum, we would ask you to demonstrate to the police that your, uh… instrument is really what it seems from the outside. Please show it in action. At least for five to ten minutes.’
‘But there aren’t any batteries or motors,’ I babble.
‘That’s not what we mean.’
‘And what then?’
I am an offended innocence itself. There are tears in my eyes, but you can’t fool Mamelukes and Janissaries. They swell with menacing Turkish testosterone:
‘Since you are so misunderstanding, Khanum, we will have to detain you indefinitely…’
And so I am being taken to an underground prison where hundreds of unbroken girls are languishing, detained from Turkish planes for carrying silver dicks…

My country, of course, doesn’t give a damn about me. Or maybe Putin will come along with his buddy Erdogan to have fun, and the two of them will watch from behind a special transparent mirror how another girl’s will could not stand the interrogation of third degree…

When the announcement of boarding the plane pulled me out of an imaginary Turkish prison, I was already quite comfortable there, resigned myself to everything and even began to make some useful acquaintances.
It seems to have worked out.
Although who knows, maybe in Istanbul luggage is also screened before delivery? To make sure that no one is carrying ancient treasures from the province?
I have always been interested in how a courier feels at the airport, hiding ten kilos of cocaine in his suitcase. I knew that now.

The plane to Istanbul was almost empty. We took off, I curled up at the window, closed my eyes and finally relaxed. But at the very moment when the height dissolved my fears, someone sat in the next chair.
My dismay has awakened again. It is unlikely that this is just a passenger who wants to change seats, there were many options in the cabin without neighbors at all. He wanted something from me.
‘Can I talk to you?’
Good English. Maybe he wants to pick me up? All marriages are made in heaven, and that’s where we are right now.
‘About what?’ I asked half-opening my eyes.
‘About the masks you’re carrying.’
That’s right. They decided to arrest me on the plane. Feeling how the Turkish prison is turning from an erotic fantasy into an objective and very close reality, I looked up at my neighbor.

Next to me was sitting an elderly, gray-haired Turk, so dark-skinned that he would have passed for native even in Africa. But it was just a long-term sunburn, I have already learned to distinguish climatic hypersuggliness from racial.

He had a funny and touching corolla of disheveled white hair around a dark egg of his head, and such a good-natured white mustache that my fear almost passed, although, there was no rational reason for this. For some reason, I immediately felt trust and sympathy for him.
‘What are you talking about?’ I asked innocently.

‘Just don’t be afraid,’ he said. ‘I’m not from the police. I am a private person. I’ve been following your friend Frank. Unfortunately, a deceased friend. So in a way, I’ve been following you, too. Accidentally. Let me express my sympathy for your grief…’

His face depicted all the proper emotions, and so diligently that my sympathy for him was finally strengthened. No, I guessed my drama hardly burns through his heart. But, in any case, he observed the proprieties very diligently. A Turkish gentleman. However, maybe there are such cops here?
‘How long have you been following us?’
‘Since Istanbul.’
‘Why? The people who killed Frank were watching us, too.’
He waved his hands.
‘Oh, that’s very, very different. No crime.’
‘It seems to me that spying on someone who doesn’t know about it is already a crime.’

‘Frank knew,’ said the gentleman. ‘But he didn’t mind. We were acquainted with him. We met and talked several times. He thought I was crazy. A harmless madman… But I’m not crazy. I won’t do any harm to you. Let me introduce myself — Ahmet Gokcen, professor at Istanbul University. Faculty of Letters.’
Is this a faculty where they study some kind of correspondence? Alphabets? Or literature? But I felt too awkward to ask.
He handed me a brown card with a gold edge.
‘There’s a phone and email. Be sure to keep it, this is my private card, not an official one. And you are Alexandra Orlova, I already know.’

He called me “Alexandra”, as in the passport. I always introduced myself as Sasha, which means he found out my name at the hotel or somewhere else, through documents. Unless, of course, he really is not from the police.
I put the card in my pocket.
‘Why were you following Frank? What’s going on anyway? Do you know why he was killed?’

‘Oh, how to explain… You see, you can… how should I say… in general, this mystery has many levels. And I need to understand how deeply you’ve penetrated it. Only then will I know how to answer your question correctly so as not to create new problems.’
‘What mystery?’
‘The one connected with the masks of Caracalla. The Great Mystery…’
‘Great mystery?’
Gokcen made a serious face. Exaggeratedly serious, and I realized that he was really going to be serious.
‘Tell me, have you ever heard the phraseSol Invictus from Frank?’
‘Yes… I remember the expression. But I’m not sure I understand him correctly. How does it translate?’
‘The Invincible Sun. One of the names of the solar deity.’
‘Yes, exactly. I remember now.’
‘In fact, these words have another meaning, a secret and very ancient one. Is that what he was talking about?’
‘Definitely not about that.’
‘Good,’ Gokcen said. ‘And about Emperor Elagabalus?’
‘No.’
‘And about thecentral projector?’
I was thinking.
‘No, there was no such thing either.’
‘So,’ he said, ‘as I thought, you haven’t penetrated the mystery very deeply.’

‘I don’t know what mystery you’re talking about,’ I replied, ‘but I’ve dived into the history of Caracalla to the full depth there is. And Frank could talk about different gods and goddesses for hours, too.’

‘You just scratched the surface. It’s so deep… not just a mystery. It is, one might say, a mystery of mysteries. It’s like a black hole. A person does not understand what is hidden there. But if he passes close enough, a powerful gravity changes the route of his fate. That’s what happened to Frank. The mystery caught him and threw him towards his death.’
‘He repeated the story of Caracalla,’ I said.
‘It’s more likely the same thing happened to Caracalla,’ Gokcen whispered. ‘Exactly the same as with Frank.’
‘But Caracalla didn’t copy anyone.’

‘He didn’t copy anyone, except maybe Alexander the Great. Caracalla was too close to the secret — and it crushed him. Frank and Caracalla, if you like, are brothers in misfortune. They had to die so that the situation could develop further. So that those who come next can join the game.’
‘Will they kill me too?’
‘You? I don’t know, I’m not a fortune teller. In this mystery, everyone has their own role. Its participants move in orbits. It all depends on what orbit you’re in. It will be found out soon.’
‘Where?’
‘Where you’re going.’
‘Do you know where I’m going?’
Gokcen nodded.
‘You’re going to give away the masks. Well, or you think you’re going to give them away.’
‘To whom?’
‘To those who gave them to Frank.’
‘And what will happen to me next?’

Gokcen made a super serious face again. By this point, I already understood why he was making this pained grimace — the rest of the time he looked so frivolous that any of his words were perceived as a joke.

‘Here, Alexandra, there are two possible options. The first one is the easiest and safest for you. This mystery will let you go, so to speak, and you will go on about your business. The comet flew past the black hole, turned slightly and flew off into space to turn tail… The second option is not so harmless anymore. You also become part of the mystery. You get your own personal orbit around the black hole. It can be very far away, like Frank’s — or, on the contrary, very close, so that you will know everything — and you will eventually fall into this hole. Both in the first and the second case, it is difficult to predict what will happen to you.’
‘Am I going to die?’

‘Not necessarily,’ Gokcen replied. ‘Frank just got on the trajectory of Caracalla, which really leads to death. There are many different orbits around this mystery, a lot. Not everyone leads to death. But, to be honest, this also happens…’
‘Do you know who killed him and why?’
‘If I had known, I would have reported it to the police,’ he said. ‘I can only speculate.’
‘Who did it?’
‘I do not know who exactly. But I can guess why.’
‘Why?’

‘There is a power… Let’s just say, there are people guarding the peace and safety of this world. They know that Emperor Caracalla was killed at one time to prevent him from entering the temple of the Moon. Perhaps this visit could have ended in something horrible…’
‘Why?’
‘Caracalla came from a very unusual family. His mother Julia Domna was originally from Syria. From Emesa. Does that mean anything to you?’
I shook my head negatively.
‘Imagine, your family has been serving the Sun for centuries. And you decided to defect to the Moon… Should you be surprised if some power will try to stop you?’
‘Do you think that’s the case?’

‘I don’t know. Just one of the assumptions. One thing is clear — for some reason they did not want to allow Caracalla into the temple of the Moon. And it was so serious that the Roman emperor — just think for a moment, the Roman emperor — had to be assassinated! And two thousand years later, a man appeared who made contact with Caracalla, even in a certain sense became him himself. And this man is trying to get to the ruins of the temple of the Moon for an unknown purpose. What do you think these guards should do?’
‘But Frank… He was almost just playing around…’
‘Maybe. But these people never play around.’
‘You’re scaring me,’ I said. ‘So they weren’t terrorists?’
Gokcen shrugged his shoulders.
‘I’m not saying I’m sure. I’m just guessing.’
‘I don’t want to take these masks anywhere anymore. I want to throw them away. Maybe I’ll give them to you? Do you want to?’
Gokcen smiled.
‘I would like, of course, to have two such excellent artifacts in my collection. But that’s not possible.’
‘Why?’
‘I don’t want to risk. These masks are alive and can bite very hard. They find their owner themselves. And they guard him or her. So you don’t have to worry about the police.’
‘I’m not the owner. I’m just a courier.’
Something close to pity flashed in Gokcen’s eyes.
‘Tell me, just be honest. Did you wear one of those masks?’
‘I did.’
‘Just trying on? Or… don’t be embarrassed, I know what they do in these masks.’
‘Or,’ I replied. ‘And many times.’
Gokcen grunted.
‘Well, then I’ll be surprised if the masks let you go. You see, these are very powerful objects — they gain power over the one who wears them. This is especially true of the Sun mask.’
‘What kind of power?’
‘They begin to dictate to people their actions.’
I suddenly felt really scared.
‘Tell me, can these masks, for example, make one person write another a note asking them to deliver them somewhere?’

‘They’re capable of anything you can think of,’ Gokcen replied. ‘And a lot of things you wouldn’t even imagine. But if you’re under the power of the mask, you won’t understand it. You will think that you are fulfilling your own wish.’
‘And what does it take to get under the power of the mask?’
‘Put it on. At least once, if we talk about the Sun mask. They have an excellent memory.’
I thought about it for a moment.
‘Is it dangerous to wear only a Sun mask?’
‘It is more dangerous. The Moon has rather an auxiliary function. But in general, these masks have the same power. It just manifests itself in different ways…’
‘Is one of them male, the other female?’
‘No. One is the Sun, the other is the Moon.’
‘Tell me, why do they have such power? Because of these stones?’
Gokcen nodded.
‘And what are the stones on them? It’s not jewelry, but some kind of black… I don’t know, basalt?’
Gokcen smiled.
‘It’s too early to talk about it now. Or rather, it’s already late.’
‘Why?’
He held up his hand, showing me his watch.

‘We’re going down. I’m going to my seat. When we get off the plane, don’t come close to me. We don’t need to be seen together. You have my card. If you feel that you are stuck in this story deeper, get in touch with me. I’ll tell you a lot of interesting things. You won’t hear that from your friends.’
‘Do you know them?’
He shook his head vaguely.
‘I do, but it’s better not to tell them about our meeting yet.’
‘And if they ask?’
‘If they ask, tell them. That’s it, I’m saying goodbye. Waiting for your call.’
He got up and left the salon without looking around. His stooped back was still visible to me when a pictograph with belts lit up above his head. We were flying over Istanbul.
I looked at the card left by Gokcen.
It was a rectangle of brown plastic with a golden edge.

p.emphasis: Prof. Dr. Ahmet Gökcen

section.p: Only phone and email on Protonmail. From communication with Antosha, I knew that this provider is very popular in online stores of high, because it is another Swiss proxy of the American special services, created specifically for people who do not fully trust Google because of the American special services, and they will never squeal on their own cocaine buyer to Russian pigs.
Let’s see, mister, what are your bookmarks… I turned the card over.
There was no any name there either. Only the gold embossing is a statue of a lion holding a paw on a small globe. Nice.
Maybe they’re all just nuts? Both Frank and this Gokcen. And then I too, since I’m taking these fucking masks somewhere after all.
I don’t know why, but I was afraid to keep this card. In a taxi, I took a picture of it on my phone, tore the original into pieces and threw it out the window.
Hopefully it was biodegradable plastic.

p.emphasis: Emoji of a beautiful sad blonde who does not stop thinking about environmental issues, even in a situation of great personal grief.png

section.p: The Aurora was moored at the Atakoy Marina, at the same pier as the last time. I called the number So left me, and she immediately picked up the phone.
‘Sasha? Hello, darling. Are you okay?’
‘Yes,’ I said. ‘I brought masks.’
‘Where are you?’
‘At the yacht. Right there at the ramp.’
So was silent for a few seconds.
‘Why didn’t you warn me? I’m in the city, I won’t be back for a couple of hours.’
‘What should I do? Meet you in the city?’
‘No way,’ said So. ‘I call Tim and he’ll meet you. Be sure to wait for me, girl. I’ll be there soon. That’s it, I can’t talk right now.’
She hung up. A minute passed, and Tim appeared upstairs.
He was wearing a light silk robe, painted like a hussar uniform, in the style of The Beatles’ uniform on the cover of the “Lonely Hearts Club”.

I already understood by this moment how such an outfit harmonizes with the coloring of the yacht, and was even imbued with a certain respect for Tim’s efforts to create and maintain an image. Desology, as it was said. All this required attention, effort and must have cost a lot of money.
Tim waved at me, and I went up the ramp, dragging my bag behind me. Tim made no attempt to help. An American, I thought. He’s afraid I’ll sue.
‘Hi,’ he said, gently hugging me. ‘What a shit, it’s just awful what happened.’
These words, as I guessed, expressed an extreme degree of grief.
‘At least, Frank died like a Roman emperor. We’re unlikely to die as beautifully. Poor guy. Did you love him?’

I nodded. Then shrugged. Stupid question. I would’ve been able to answer it for sure in a couple of years. We didn’t even have time to get used to each other — how long did we spend together? Two weeks or so…
‘So will be back soon,’ Tim said, ‘but it’s a good thing she’s not here. Come to my office. You probably have million of questions.’
‘Not exactly a million,’ I replied, ‘but I have some.’

Tim turned and walked forward. After a minute of traveling through a sparkling with nickel and polished walnut anarchist squat, we came to his office. All this time I was dragging the bag behind me, because no one took it from me.

The first thing that caught my eye in his office was the leather-covered wall behind his desk. It looked a little strange: it passed exactly through the center of the round porthole, without touching it, as if the cabin had been larger before, and it had been hastily divided by a partition.

But even in a truncated form, the office looked like the office of a corporate executive who got used to live with guts inside out: life trophies in the form of obscure cups, glazed photographs with gift strokes, diplomas, inscribed golf clubs and other memorabilia merged into a kind of resume telling about an impeccable and wisely invested life.
The photographs on Tim’s desk were turned to face the visitor, so that no one could avoid looking into the glorious past of the owner.

In one of them, Tim was standing next to Steve Jobs, and explaining something to him, pointing at a piece of paper. Steve Jobs was late — in a black turtleneck, with a sharpened face and that expression of barely noticeable irony that replaces the deathbed despair of strong people.

In another photo, Tim was standing with a young So in his arms. He looked almost the same as he is now, and So looked a little like me, which for some reason was pleasant to me. On the third, Tim was photographed with Bernie Sanders, and on the fourth, which especially impressed me, with an unknown man whose silhouette was carefully blackened with a marker. Perhaps some Epstein or Weinstein was standing there, whom decency demanded to erase from memory — but the photo was turned to the viewer along with the others, as if to inform that, although there are unpleasant memories and connections in Tim’s past, he personally is not involved in anything bad, because otherwise he would hardly have left such a certificate in plain sight.
It was subtle.

I sat down in front of the bag and opened the zipper, intending to pull out a bag with masks (I’ll give it along with handcuffs and everything else, let them sort it out themselves), when suddenly my hands froze. I forgot about the masks and slowly straightened up.

To the side above Tim’s desk was a glazed shelf that housed a collection of small, palm-high, painted busts. The greenish glass was half closed, and the figures blurred behind it into cucumber spots. But two busts remained visible.
Nefertiti was standing in the back, I recognized her immediately, although instead of the usual chess rook, she had a black wig on her head: almost a modern square haircut. It suited her.

Frank was closer. In a purple cape with the hood pulled down from his head. It was Frank in the image of Caracalla, not Caracalla himself — there was a difference between them, and I knew it by heart. It was caught here for sure.
But the most horrifying detail turned out to be a black hole with a dark spot around, painted under the collarbone.
It occurred to me that Tim had deliberately opened the glass on the shelf.
‘Have you…’ Unable to pronounce the name, I nodded at Frank’s bust, ‘Have you set this up?’
‘What are you talking about?’
‘About his death.’
‘Absolutely not,’ Tim replied, ‘Do you think I hired assassins and sent them after the poor boy? I don’t do such things. Well, almost.’
‘And what was your role then?’
‘I financed his romantic lifestyle for a while. And helped him to meet you. Or rather, So and the circumstances helped. But we didn’t plan anything in advance. I swear to you.’
‘Really?’
‘In short,’ Tim continued, ‘there’s some kind of power doing all this. I introduced Frank to it, and it gave him a dream. And then it let his dream come true.’
‘What kind of power?’
‘It’s too early to talk about it.’
‘What kind of dream are you talking about? Did he dream of being stabbed to death?’

‘No,’ Tim replied, ‘he wanted to meet the lunar deity to whom Caracalla once went. It was love, deep and ancient — it emerged from eternity and possessed him. His love wasn’t you. You served as a hanger for the mask.’
I blushed.
‘Do you even know such details?’
‘No one was spying on you, calm down. I just know how Frank behaved and what he was aiming for.’
‘Did you understand that he would be killed? Only honestly.’
Tim frowned.
‘Not quite,’ he said at last. ‘Let’s just say I guessed that this strange project would have a strange ending. Perhaps fiery and unusual.’
‘But you could have warned him!’
‘About what? About the fate of Caracalla? He knew more about him than all the current historians.’
‘Yes,’ I said, ‘it’s true. He knew a lot about antiquity.’
‘And even not from people,’ Tim said, ‘but from antiquity itself. I’ve seen this many times before. But I’m interested in something else. I would like to understand your place in this scheme.’
‘Do you think there is one?’

‘Look for yourself. First, you are met by So — not somewhere, but in Roman Sofia, and then brought to visit us. It could still be an accident. But then Frank leaves with you. And you bring him right to the denouement.’
‘Me? To the denouement? I just listened to him and agreed to everything…’
‘You either don’t understand how a woman leads a man to a denouement,’ Tim said, ‘or you pretend you don’t understand.’

It was unexpected. And is not stupid at all — I didn’t even find what to answer. Still, I’m not a feminist enough. Or rather, my feminism always betrays me at the most important moment. Or am I betraying it?
‘You put on the mask yourself, didn’t you?’
‘Yes,’ I said.
‘You wore a mask of the Moon. You were the lover of the Sun. And now you came to me with both masks.’
‘That’s what Frank asked…’
He waved his hand, as if he was annoyed by my empty words.
‘You’re in the game, my girl. If you conduct it correctly, everything will be fine. If not, tragedy may happen to you as well. And I won’t be the one who arranges it, believe me.’
‘Then who will?’
‘I don’t know how to answer this question yet. The Universe. Who arranged Frank’s death? Two random bastards. The police have no questions or suspicions. So they won’t arise about you either.’
‘Are you threatening me now?’
‘No,’ Tim said, ‘I’m not threatening, quite the opposite. I want to protect you.’
‘From whom? From what?’
‘I don’t know how to explain yet. That’s the point.’
‘What happens if I leave?’
Tim shrugged.
‘I don’t know. Maybe nothing. Or maybe there will be a tragic accident in which the people around you won’t see anything supernatural…’
Somehow I knew he was telling the truth. I even turned pale, as the mirror on the wall informed me.
‘What am I supposed to do now?’
‘I’d ask Frank,’ Tim replied, ‘he’s the one who got you into this mess.’
‘What?’ I frowned. ‘What did you just say?’
‘I said the best option to do is to check it with Frank. He already knows everything.’
‘Is he alive?’
‘You saw him at the morgue.’
‘Then how are you going to…’
‘For this we will have to go out of the city,’ Tim said and looked at his watch. ‘It will be dark soon, it’s about time. If you’re ready, I’ll give the necessary orders.’
‘What are we going to do?’
‘You’ll see. Don’t be afraid. It’s not dangerous.’
I thought about it.

There really was nothing to be afraid of. If they wanted to kill me, there wouldn’t be a more convenient place than this yacht anyway. But why would they kill me? I brought the masks myself, I don’t know any dark secrets…

I didn’t like what was happening too much. After what happened with Frank, I was fed up with adventures, and I was not keen to take part in any questionable procedures, whatever they were. On the other hand, what happened to Frank, his incredible death, this shadow of Caracalla that crushed him, which I didn’t even really know about two weeks ago, convinced me that Tim was telling the truth.
I still had the masks. Frank put them in my bag so I could give them to Tim. And he hasn’t taken them yet… it’s good that I remembered. I unzipped the bag, but got distracted and forgot…
I suddenly felt uneasy. Or maybe it’s the masks don’t want this to happen? Maybe that’s why I forgot?
‘Take the masks.’
‘Not right now,’ Tim replied. ‘It’s not that simple.’
‘Why?’
‘Because they decide who they want to be with. We’ll find out today.’
‘How?’
‘So will come back and explain everything to you. You understand each other well, don’t you?’
I nodded.
‘That’s nice.’
‘I need to go to the bathroom,’ I said. ‘Take a shower and change.’
‘It’s possible. They’ll help you. When you’re done, go down to the pier. A car will be waiting for us.’
The yacht’s staff also wore uniforms in the style of the Lonely Hearts Club — a fake uniform with medals, epaulettes, aiguillettes and stripes printed on the fabric.

It turned out democratic — the owner and the employees were dressed the same. Well, almost the same — Tim was wearing a silk robe, and the steward, who was dragging my bag down the corridor, was wearing a light cotton robe. There may also have been medals and rank signs printed on the fabric, but I have not penetrated so deeply into the question yet.

I liked the cabin. It resembled a small room in a good hotel — most of the space was occupied by a bed, on one side of it there was a bedside table, and on the other — two neat windows, behind which the evening sky was dark and the sea was almost the same color with it. There were also masts sticking out, a lot of budget masts.

The resemblance to the hotel was complete — a stand for a bag, a kettle on a mirrored table, a small neat bathroom with a shower. There was a dressing gown hanging there (a yellow hussar uniform with one shoulder strap and a medal with a heraldic lion on the chest). Slippers with painted pompoms lay on the floor. Apparently, it was a guest cabin.

There were two taps in the shower. Above one is an enamel palm with a blue pill, and with a red one above the other. Subtly, that’s it. I turned on the tap with a red pill, but no matter how much I waited, the water never warmed up. I had to wash cold. The rich keep crying.

I had to hurry, but after the shower I quickly tried on the robe anyway. It fit perfectly. The right decision from the point of view of Desology. A good crew does everything in formation, even drowning in the abyss. The pirate brotherhood. We’re all sailors now.

p.emphasis: Emoji of a legless sailor with a bottle prosthesis and a small illegible face because who cares about legless sailors’ legible faces, even if yesterday they were beautiful young blondes.png

section.p: When I went down the ramp, the car was already parked at the pier. It was, I think, a Rolls-Royce — in the semi-darkness it looked like a giant black toad crouching down before jumping. However, as soon as the driver opened the door, the delusion passed — the cheerful lights on the dashboard and the quiet ambient in the speakers returned me to the bosom of civilization.

A good expression is this “the bosom of civilization”. You want to be born into the ultimate reality, and they take you and shove you back into this bosom with a squish. Probably, the man came up with this. He wanted to say that everything is under his patriarchal-phallic control.

Neither Tim nor So were in the car — apparently, I came down too early. The cabin smelled faintly of a cigar. Another interior, reminds me in every detail that I have not achieved anything in my life yet. I remember, my friends, thank you.
It was cozy and sleepy in the car. I listened to music for a few minutes. Then the door opened, and So climbed into the cabin. She was wearing jeans and a black sweater.
‘Hello, girl.’

She smiled exactly the way she should — weakly, sadly and barely noticeable, so that the joy of meeting me was somehow shaded and balanced by grief from a recent loss. I noted the surgically accurate calculation, admired this unconscious mimic balancing act — and only then realized that I was smiling back in the same way.

We hugged, and I let out a small tear. So’s eyes also glistened wetly, and we sobbed a couple of times. I am sure that at that moment she was grieving as sincerely as I was. But after a minute our tears have completely dried up.
‘Tim will be here soon. He solves organizational issues.’
‘And what exactly are we organizing?’
‘That’s what I want to explain,’ she said, glanced at the driver and pressed a button on the panel.
A smoky glass rose, and separated us from the front compartment of the car.
‘It’s not our wheels,’ So said, ‘local ones.’
‘A luxury.’
‘You can hire cheap,’ So shrugged. ‘This is not a luxury, but an imitation of it. Our age does not know luxury at all.’
‘Millionaires’ wives too?’
‘They’re too’, answered So. ‘Only the wives of some dictators know.’
‘Why?’

‘Stylistic magazines teach that luxury is to surround yourself with expensive things. But they’re lying. The real luxury — an ancient, genuine one, is to surround yourself with cheap lives. That’s what Stalin did. Or Caracalla… oh, I shouldn’t have remembered him.’
‘It’s nothing,’ I said. ‘I’m already tired to be scared.’
‘That’s right,’ So said. ‘Do you remember, we talked about Sofia in ancient times?’
‘I remember,’ I replied. ‘Radical avant-garde. A bright future.’
‘Exactly. You saw this church through the eyes of a sixth-century Roman. Today you need to repeat the same trick, but dive into the past much deeper. To understand what it was then…’
‘What is it?’ I asked.
‘Necromancy,’ So said.
Apparently, my face reflected my feelings, because So grinned.
‘You see. From this sound alone, a lot of cholesterol plaques broke off from the walls of your brain. It is precisely such cultural remains that need to be neutralized.’
‘Is this some kind of black magic?’
‘Sort of it is,’ So replied. ‘But not really.’
‘So yes or no?’

‘Necromancy is a seventeenth-century English word,’ So said. ‘It is converted from the Italiannigromancia, which means, as you just noticed, “black magic”. In the Middle Ages, it was such a… sort of official church witchcraft.’
‘Official one?’

‘Not quite. Various Catholic priests, sometimes even the popes themselves, altered masses and prayers for magical purposes, trying to control evil spirits with the help of, so to speak, hacked Christian code. This was condemned, but it was spread roughly like corruption in Russian law enforcement agencies.’
‘I see.’
She smiled.
‘But there is also the Latin wordnecromantia’, she continued, ‘and it comes from a very, very old, still preclassical Greek termnecromantea, consisting of the words “dead” and…’
‘Divination,’ I said, ‘I know.’

‘That’s right. The wordnecromancy meant “questioning the dead”. Or an appeal to the dead for divination purposes. This is a venerable and ancient science. Initially, there was no macabre in it, and many ancient heroes used it.’
‘Good or bad?’ I asked.

‘Both of them. You can read it on the way, I’ve got a book for you. You need to tune in, girl. What you will see may seem strange, cruel and even perverted. But this is not because this is the ritual itself. This is how our eyes see him today…’
‘Cruel?’ I asked. ‘Are we going to kill someone?’
So nodded.
‘Who?’
‘A sheep. The black sheep. They are slaughtered daily on cattle farms — we just transfer this procedure to another place. We’ll need her blood. But the animal will die quickly and painlessly.’
‘I see,’ I said. ‘And we won’t kill people?’
‘We won’t,’ So said. ‘I promise.’
‘Are we going to communicate with the dead?’
‘In a way.’
‘With whom?’
‘With those who will come. It doesn’t always depend on us. Perhaps someone ancient will come.’
‘Tim,’ I whispered, ‘was talking about Frank.’
‘I hope he comes too,’ So said. ‘You were close to him. It works.’
I shook my head in disbelief.
‘But how can you communicate with the souls of the dead? Are they sitting somewhere and waiting to be called?’

‘It’s complicated,’ said So. ‘It is certainly possible to question souls. They respond, and in a very meaningful way. But I’m not sure that these souls exist at a time when no one is talking to them.’
‘To answer, they have to come from somewhere.’

‘Not necessarily,’ So said. ‘They can arise from non-existence for exactly the time while they are being communicated with. I suspect that this is the case. It is as if we create them with our questioning, and by answering us, they acquire a new existence. Like an echo in an information matrix. The new life of the spirit being questioned is very short — it ends immediately after the answer to the question.’
‘So we wake them up? Or are we creating them?’
So twirled her hand in the air, showing that this terminological subtlety is not too important.
Tim finally appeared in the front seat. So pressed the button, and the window rolled down.
‘We can go,’ Tim said. ‘Everything is ready.’
‘Sasha asks what we do with necromancy,’ So said. ‘Do we raise the dead, or do we create their likeness?’
‘I don’t know,’ Tim shrugged. ‘What does it matter.’
‘And what does such a spirit look like?’ I asked.
‘It doesn’t look anything,’ Tim said. ‘It speaks.’
‘How?’
‘You’ll find out soon…’
Tim turned to the driver and said something in Turkish. The car rumbled and screwed into the already thickening night.
I kept calm, but I was scared. Or rather, I was damn scared. First Frank, then this… And why did I go to give away the masks? I could have just thrown them into the sea.
However, if I could, I probably would have done so. But I didn’t.
So put an open book on my lap.
‘Read it for now,’ she said. ‘Is it dark for you?’
She touched the panel in front of us, and a cone of light fell into my lap. In this car it was possible not only to ride, but also to live.
‘What is this book?’
‘Odyssey’, So answered. ‘An old, 19th century edition. This is good, because the modern translation looks like… I don’t know, hyperrealistic. And you’re not very comfortable anyway, are you?’
Oddly enough, after these words, I felt calm.
‘What exactly to read?’
‘Only underlined.’
Underlined, or rather, highlighted with a yellow marker, was a lot.

v.emphasis: Perimedes and Eurylochus held the victims fast,
and I, drawing my sharp sword from beside my hip,
dug a trench of about a forearm's depth and length
and around it poured libations out to all the dead,
first with milk and honey, and then with mellow wine,
and load a pyre with treasures, and to Tiresias,
alone, apart, I would offer a sleek black ram.
the pride of all my herds. And once my vows
and prayers had invoked the nations of the dead,
I took the victims, over the trench I cut their throats
and the dark blood flowed in - and up out of Erebus they came,
flocking toward me now, the ghosts of the dead and gone
Brides and unwed youths and old men who had suffered much
and girls with their tender hearts freshly scarred by sorrow
and great armies of battle dead, stabbed by bronze spears,
men of war still wrapped in bloody armor - thousands
swarming around the trench from every side,
unearthly cries-blanching terror gripped me!
I ordered the men at once to flay the sheep
that lay before us, killed by my ruthless blade,
and burn them both, and then say prayers to the gods.
to the almighty Hades and dread Persephone.
But I, the sharp sword drawn from beside my hip,
sat on alert there and never let the ghosts
of the shambling, shiftless dead come near that blood
till I had questioned Tiresias myself.

section.p: The book was old, and smelled, as it seemed to me, of a damp grave. Everyone who wrote in this strange English has long since disappeared into the ground. But the translation was made almost into a modern language, if we compare the time when it was made with the abyss of time separating us from the Odyssey.
‘Girls with their tender hearts freshly scarred by sorrow,’ I repeated.
So nodded.
‘It’s sad, that’s right. And now see it with antique eyes.’
‘How?’

‘We are all standing on the threshold of Hades,’ So replied. ‘We can say that we die during our lifetime — decaying, aging, getting sick. But our heads are still here, in the world of the living. And those who went to Hades have already lowered them to where everything is visible. Absolutely everything — all sorts of where, what and how. And we ask those who are already there to explain to us what is happening here.’
‘And why can the dead see everything?’

‘I don’t know,’ said So. ‘I haven’t descended into Hades yet. In ancient times, it was believed that the shadows of the deceased acquire omniscience by merging with the world spirit. That is, with God. Therefore, when we ask the dead, we are actually asking God, who answers us by taking familiar and understandable forms.’
‘To be honest, it seems a little strange to me that a spirit-god comes to necromancers to drink sheep’s blood,’ I said, ‘and responds exclusively after the treat.’

‘And why not?’ So smiled. ‘The silliest thing is to apply human concepts and standards to God. Maybe he’s having fun answering with the voices of the deceased. Maybe it’s cool for gods to drink sheep’s blood.’
‘He’s probably got tired of the human one,’ I said.
So nodded.
‘Therefore, it is better to keep the mind open…’
I gave her the book, turned off the light on the panel and stared out the dark window.

There were flashes of light on the glass. There was nothing mysterious about them — lanterns, lamps in roadside windows, red eyes of cars, but I liked to think that I was looking into the depths of Hades and seeing spirits floating there. Then I got scared again.
‘Where are we going?’ I asked.
‘To the Yarimburgaz Cave,’ she said in such a tone as if mentioning McDonald’s or a gas station.
‘Yarim… and what is it?’

‘Just a cave twenty kilometers from Istanbul. A very ancient place, people lived there in the Paleolithic. Then there were pagan temples, Byzantine churches, Hollywood shootings and so on. A lot of different things happened there — but we only care about the fact that in ancient times the souls of the deceased were summoned there. The cave remembers it. And that’s why such a thing is still possible.’
‘And not in other places anymore?’
So shrugged.
‘It’s better to stick to reliable ancient sites.’
Our Rolls-Royce left the highway, drove a little on the ground and stopped near a small campsite, as it seemed to me at first. We got out (the driver stayed in the car) and headed to this campsite.

After a few steps, I realized that it was just a few cars parked near the highway: two vans and a pickup truck. People were sitting on folding stools nearby. They were talking quietly; a cigarette dot was trembling in the dark. They were waiting for us.
Tim said something in Turkish. He’s been answered in English. He told me and So to wait in place, went ahead and stopped in the light of the headlights.
A loose man with a complicated mustache, similar to sideburns that had moved under his nose, approached him. He shook Tim’s hand, and they began to confer. They talked for quite a long time.

The setting was like a meeting of two Mexican drug cartels in a Hollywood movie of catYegory “B”, shot by a moderately left-wing homosexual director: stylish, folky, with a keen interest in the colorful male texture, but too low-budget. I swear, that’s what I thought — that’s what digital capitalism does to our consciousness.

Two sturdy Turks in casual jeans arrived with a mustachioed fat man. There was also a middle-aged dyed blonde in a summer dress, with large wooden beads around her neck. They all stood at a distance and did not get involved in the conversation.

Then a boy of about fourteen came out from behind the pickup truck, whom I didn’t notice right away, looking like a typical schoolboy in shorts. His presence calmed me down — after all, children are not taken for wet work. Although… It depends. In Brazil, for example, children are sent to it.
Tim turned to us and waved his hand. We could go.
By this time, my eyes had already gotten used to the darkness, and I could clearly make out a low ridge of light stone ahead, even at night. It was where we went, stretching out in a long chain.

When he reached the cliff, one of the denim Turks turned on the flashlight. There was an ink hole in the stone wall, covered with an iron grate. The second Turk unlocked it with a key, opened the door in the grille, let everyone go inside, and locked it again behind me. It seemed ominous to me, and I looked at So.
‘So that we wouldn’t be interrupted,’ she smiled. ‘There are all sorts of extreme lovers here. Amateur archaeologists, drug addicts, homeless… They lock it up to keep them away.’

That’s it, I thought, for a millionaire’s wife, a homeless person is an extreme lover. They say to earn a lot of money, you need to get out of your comfort zone. But then you can settle in it forever. Wealth gently retouches the world, charging everything with positivity.

We walked forward through the cave, passed a fork, and I saw an electric light ahead. There was an extension of the corridor. I probably wouldn’t have noticed this place if I had come here alone — but the light turned it into a kind of small rounded room.

Everything was already prepared for the procedure. Two spotlights were burning — their soft radiance did not hurt the eyes. In the center of the stone bag was a mirror on supports, in front of it was a comfortable office chair.
There was another lamp behind the chair — a halogen lamp on a long rod. Its reflector, raised above the back of the chair, was reflected in the mirror.
But that wasn’t all.

Two small black sheep were lying against the wall with their legs tied and their muzzles wrapped with duct tape, and honestly, it looked like a continuation of the same Mexican action movie I was thinking about ten minutes ago. The sheep behaved calmly, they just squinted at us with indifferent, all-understanding eyes.

‘Here in ancient times, the dead were questioned and sacrifices were made to them,’ So said. ‘Do you see this recess? Such a groove. Sacrificial blood flowed here. If you slaughter a sheep in any other place, nothing special will happen. But if the blood gets here again, they’ll hear us…’
It was difficult to look the sheep in the eyes. How and from where does God look at a human? Yes, that’s how he looks at us…
Tim clapped his hands.
‘Here we go.’

A boy in shorts came to a chair, sat down and leaned back, taking a relaxed and lazy pose, leading to scoliosis, as I remembered from afterschool safety instructions. But today the teacher did not wake up in any of the adults.
The mustached mobster approached the halogen lamp and adjusted it so that the light reflected in the mirror fell on the boy’s face. Then he reduced the brightness to a minimum.
‘Won’t they strangle a child?’ I asked So in a whisper.
‘No,’ she said. ‘They’ll hypnotize him.’
‘Isn’t it dangerous?’
‘No. They do this often. A family of professionals.’
Soft music started playing, a string folk. It was something vaguely familiar, either Spanish or Italian, and it was quite suitable for the gangster movie that I was still filming in my head.
‘Why the music?’
‘I’ll tell you later,’ So replied. ‘You’d better watch. This is interesting. You don’t see it every day.’

The boy on the chair nodded lazily to the beat of the music for a while — and then stopped. It looked like he had fallen asleep in class. Then Tim turned to one of the denim guys and ran his hand over his neck.
The Turk dragged the sheep to a groove on the floor and, before I could close my eyes, cut its throat with a folding knife.
He opened the blade with a flick of his thumb, a moment before the jerk of his hand, so I saw the gleam of steel only when the job was already done.

The sheep kicked several times. Black blood, as promised by Homer, poured into the stone trough. I thought it would fill it, but it almost immediately flowed somewhere, as if invisible greedy mouths were really drinking it.
The woman in beads came to the chair with the boy, stood next to the lamp and turned questioningly to Tim.
‘Call Bassianus,’ he said softly.
The woman apparently understood who she was talking about — she stared into the mirror and uttered a long phrase in a language I didn’t recognize. It didn’t look like Latin.
‘What kind of language is that?’ I whispered.
‘Greek. Not quite the same as today.’
‘Why not Latin?’
‘They spoke Greek,’ So whispered. ‘Be quiet and listen.’
The woman repeated the same phrase again. Then another one.
‘Bassianus is not answering,’ she said.
‘Then call Maesa or Domna,’ Tim said.

The woman in the beads began to wail again, gently and plaintively, as if coaxing the lamp reflected in the mirror. It went on for a long time, but nothing interesting happened. Then she turned to Tim and shrugged.
The Turk with the knife came up to the second sheep and stared questioningly at Tim. And at that moment, the boy curled up on the chair started speaking.
As soon as he opened his mouth, I realized it was Frank.
No, the boy was speaking in his own voice, thin and childish — but it was Frank!
‘Hi, Moonchild. Glad to see you… the dildo came in handy, right?’
‘Yes,’ I said, ‘thanks. But I forgot the collar at the hotel. Sorry…’
The boy laughed softly, just as Frank had laughed. He wasn’t looking in my direction, but in the mirror. And, it seems, he did not understand at all who he was addressing.
‘I’m sorry about what happened,’ he said. ‘Were you angry when you saw these masks in the bag? I didn’t think it would happen so fast, otherwise I would have said goodbye… are you okay?’
So and Tim were looking at me. I should’ve kept the conversation going.
‘I’m fine, aren’t you? How’s life?’
The boy giggled, and only then did the idiocy of my question sink in: “how’s life”? Naturally, I did it without any intention.
‘Great,’ Frank said. ‘Just fine. And death, too.’
‘Where are you now?’
Frank laughed again. So smiled, and I guessed that I had said something stupid again.
‘I’m here, baby. I’m right here with you. Where else can I be?’
‘I’m sorry,’ I said. ‘I’m nervous.’

‘Don’t worry,’ he said. ‘Everything will be fine. You should know… you’ve already been told, and it’s true. I didn’t leave you the masks by accident. You’re the Moon. The Moon attracts the Sun. Find the real Sun.’
‘How?’
‘You know.’
‘I don’t really know.’
‘You know how to search,’ Frank repeated.
I realized that arguing with him was stupid.
‘Tell me, are you happy?’ I asked. ‘Do you feel good?’
‘I’m with you now, and I’m feeling good. I’m with you now, and I’m happy.’
‘When I leave, where will you be?’
‘I don’t know,’ Frank replied.
‘And where did you come from?’
‘I didn’t come,’ Frank said. ‘I was with you.’
‘How?’
‘Everyone who died. They are always with you. They live through you. You live for them. You are their window into life. You are them.’
‘What do you mean?’
The boy sniffed for a while.

‘You are us,’ he said at last. ‘And we are you. We look through you at this world. While this is going on, you think you’re living. You see and hear for us. You are all the previous generations looking into the windows of your feelings.’
‘And what do you do when you don’t look into them?’

‘We always look out the windows. There is nothing else. You won’t understand. I didn’t understand either. The dead, the living are philosophical ideas. In fact, there is nothing like that. There is fresh skin. It grinds against the world and comes down layer by layer. Another grows in its place. We are all the same.’
‘And why does your spirit come to drink blood?’
Having finished the question, I immediately regretted it. But nothing terrible happened. The boy laughed hoarsely, and I recognized Frank’s laugh again, as if reproduced at a slightly faster speed.

‘Good question,’ he said. ‘There are certain formalities in life that exist so that entities can meet. For example, embassy receptions. Dinner parties. Calling a prostitute. Contract killing. Or such rituals connecting life and death. In addition, fresh sheep’s blood is very tasty. You’ll like it…’
‘Is it possible to connect life and death?’ I asked.
‘Of course,’ the boy replied. ‘Life is an illusion. Death is also an illusion. Two illusions don’t need to be connected. They’re already the same thing.’
It was unclear whether Frank was joking or serious. On the other hand, I didn’t always understand it during his lifetime.
‘Did you find what you were looking for?’ I asked. ‘What did you strive for? Have you met a goddess?’

‘Yes,’ the boy replied. ‘The goddess accepted me the same way she accepted Caracalla. The gods do not betray those who love them. They betray only those who bargain with them… I didn’t understand before. Now I see more. I see everything.’
‘What do you see?’
‘I wasn’t the one the gods were looking for. Caracalla, too. The one the gods were looking for came after him. He will come after me again. Through you.’
‘Through me?’
‘Like through a door,’ he said.
‘What do you mean?’ So, who had been silent before, spoke up. ‘Is Sasha asoldator?’
That strange word, if I heard it correctly, told me nothing. But I remembered it.

‘She will open the door,’ Frank said. ‘She will open the door, and the sun will smile at her. And a dazzling butterfly will fly into the room. As in the Mithraeum on the Gallic street… She will bring the one you are looking for.’
‘How?’ So asked. ‘How will she do it?’
‘She knows how to search. She’ll need masks.’
When So entered into our conversation, it seemed to me that Frank began to move away somewhere, although I did not know what exactly this was expressed in.
‘Frank,’ I asked, ‘what should I do?’
‘They’ll tell you,’ Frank said. ‘Don’t try to throw off this burden. Otherwise you’ll die as stupidly as I did. The Stone sees you.’
‘You’re scaring me,’ I said plaintively. ‘What kind of burden? What stone?’
‘You’ll find out everything.’
‘When?’
‘The Sun Mask will tell about itself.’
The boy fell silent. He was silent for a very long time this time, and I realized that Frank was no longer with us.

Tim made a sign to the Turk, and he cut the throat of the second sheep. The blood flowed into the hollow of the stone, disappeared, but the boy remained silent. And then he opened his eyes and said something in Turkish.
‘That’s it,’ Tim translated. ‘No one else will come.’

p.emphasis: Emoji of a beautiful blonde cautiously coming out of a cave where something dark, occult and most likely illegal has just happened.png

section.p: On the way back, Tim got into the back seat next to me and rolled up the window. Apparently, the goal was to prevent me from talking to So, who was sitting in front.
My questions remained unanswered — Tim kept repeating the same thing:
‘At home. We’ll discuss it at home.’

The car stopped at the pier. We went out, Tim took me firmly by the hand and led me to the yacht, like a dad who lead a naughty daughter back home. So fell behind, and I realized that we were going to have a one-on-one conversation.

In the office, he put me on a chair, and he sat on the table, dangling his legs from it. For some reason it occurred to me that this was how Clinton behaved in the oval office when Monica Lewinsky did “metoo” to him (I remember, when Frank first designated this procedure in this way, I winced in disgust — and here I am, repeating myself). Indeed, Clinton was probably sitting on the president’s desk with his legs spread. How else?
And all the other presidents since then have been looking into the imprint of the Clinton butt and deciding the fate of the world. Surely it affects the world somehow, but how?
I liked that I could be distracted by such thoughts after everything I had experienced. So, I have a stable psyche, and life goes on no matter what.
‘Well,’ Tim asked, ‘are you convinced now? I wouldn’t have thought of that. And this Turkish boy is even more so. He doesn’t even speak much English.’
‘What is asoldator’? I asked.
‘It’s a Latin pun.’
‘What’s its meaning?’

‘There is a Latin wordsaltator, a dancer. It is from the wordsalta — “to jump”. One ancient sect that worshipped the Sun wrote the wordsaltator with an “o”, so it turned outsoltator, “sun” and “dance” merged into one. In English, you can say “sundancer”.’
‘And what does this have to do with Frank and Caracalla?’
‘Nothing. Caracalla died on his way to the Moon, just like a Soviet cosmonaut. He was sure that he himself was the solar deity. Just by imperial right. But he was wrong.’
‘Now I know,’ I said.
‘But the most interesting thing began later. Do you know what happened after Caracalla’s death?’
‘No,’ I said. ‘I don’t know much about history.’

‘When Caracalla was assassinated, the Praetorian prefect Macrinus became the emperor — historians believe that he organized the conspiracy and sent the murderer. But Macrinus was disliked by the soldiers, to whom he reduced the salary inflated by Caracalla. Caracalla officially had no children, and the Severan dynasty was interrupted. But soon after the emperor’s death, rumors began to circulate among the soldiers of the Third Gallic Legion stationed in Syria about the bastard of Caracalla. It was a boy who lived in Emesa and performed the functions of the high priest of the solar god Elagabal.’
‘Emesa?’ I asked. ‘I’ve heard that word before.’

‘Now there is Syrian Homs. At that time, Emesa was a civilized Hellenic city, a very important center of the Roman Empire, and there was nothing barbaric about all this for the then-Romans. The boy’s name was Varius Avitus, he was fourteen years old, and he really was a relative of Caracalla on his mother’s side. Caracalla’s death simply cleared the way for him.’
‘Fourteen years?’ I was surprised. ‘Is it possible to be a high priest at that age?’

‘You are projecting our current understanding onto Eastern antiquity,’ Tim answered. ‘“High Priest” back then meant not “the administrative head of the cult, who is driven in a black limousine for lobbying the policy of the ruling oligarchy in front of believers, referring to his connections among the heavenly men”, but “the closest to God”. Little Varius danced for the Sun god. This was the main function of the priest. This took place in the main temple of Emesa, and the dance of Varius Avitus could be seen by people who had nothing to do with the cult. Including Roman soldiers…’
‘Was he thesoltator?’ I guessed. ‘The one about whom So spoke?’
Tim nodded.

‘The boy was good-looking, and his dance had such an effect on the soldiers that in the end they brought him to the camp of the Third Gallic, dressed him in the clothes that little Caracalla wore, and presented him to the army as his son. He looked like the murdered emperor because he was a close relative of his mother. Besides, he could really be his son, there is no complete clarity on this. The Roman emperors did not deny themselves anything…’
‘I guess.’

‘It was about a year after the death of Caracalla, whom the soldiers, unlike Roman historians and senators, loved very much. The boy danced in front of the soldiers, they brought him to the camp and at dawn proclaimed him the ruler of a huge empire… It was said that there was some amazing power in his dance. All the detachments sent to pacify the rebellion by the usurper Makrinus went over to his side at once.’
‘It looks like,’ I said, ‘this guy could dance really well.’
‘Here, you are already beginning to understand how things were done in ancient times. But it wasn’t just about the dance. The boy danced not just anywhere, but in front of the sacred black stone.’
‘You said he was a priest of the Sun.’

‘He did. But the solar deity of Emesa was associated with a conical black stone — the main temple shrine. After becoming emperor, Elagabalus (the new emperor was nicknamed in honor of his god, like Caracalla in honor of his cape) began to carry this shrine with him.’
‘The black stone?’ I asked.
‘Yes,’ Tim replied, ‘so-calledBet El.’
‘What is it?’

‘Translates as “the home of God”. This was the name given to stones, usually of a meteoritic nature, which were worshipped in ancient times. Most of them were destroyed by Christians. Some, however, are still in business. For example, the black stone of the Kaaba. However, according to the official version, Muslims do not worship him. For them, it’s just a reminder of the Prophet.’
‘Are the black stone of the Kaaba and the black stone of Elagabalus related to each other?’
‘Elagabalus lived four centuries before the rise of Islam. But hisBet El definitely had serious magical power. He helped an unknown boy from Syria become a Roman emperor in a year.’
‘Tell me,’ I asked, ‘are the Carrhae, where Caracalla was killed, and this Emesa — are they far from each other?’
‘They don’t. And I quite admit that the lunar deity from Carrhae may found his solar half in the new emperor… Maybe she helped this boy.’
‘Did they meet? The Goddess of the Moon and Elagabalus?’

‘I don’t know. The chronicles don’t say anything about it. After becoming emperor, Elagabalus went first to Nicomedia, and then to Rome. And he brought a black stone to the capital of the empire, in front of which he danced. There are coins where… one moment…’
Tim got off the table, walked around it, opened the top drawer and handed me a dim yellow circle the size of a 10 Euro coin.
‘This aureus was minted in the reign of Elagabalus.’
‘Gold?’ I asked, looking at the coin.
‘Yes,’ said Tim. ‘Weight seven and a half grams. Not such a numismatic rarity. They were stamped mainly in Nicomedia and Asia in general. You can buy it for about ten thousand dollars…’

On one side of the coin was the profile of a good-looking young man in a wreath. On the other is a chariot carrying something triangular. There were perfectly clear psilocybe mushrooms hanging in the air around the chariot — it was very difficult, with all the desire, to take them for something else. There was a triangular stone on the chariot, and the only word I could read was stamped under the wheels:
ELAGABAL
‘And what is written above the chariot?’

Sancto deo soli, Tim replied, ‘“the sacred deity of the Sun”, to whom the coin is dedicated. Therefore, the dative case. And some words are cut off — this was often done on coins. Numismatists call this coinAureus Sol Invictus. Do you know what “Sol Invictus” is?’
I remembered Frank in the Sun mask, then Ahmet Gokcen — and shrugged, feeling a slight chill inside.
‘Invincible Sun?’

‘Exactly. Numismatists are a bit confused. The cult of the Invincible Sun spread in Rome much later than the cult of Elagabal and was popular mainly among soldiers. This is the end of the third century, Emperor Aurelian. Practically the same as the cult of Mithra, just with another name. And the era of Elagabalus is the beginning of the third century. The expressionSol Invictus existed even then, but was not so common. It pointed to a secret known only to the initiated.’
I hesitated for a few seconds whether to say about the conversation with Ahmet Gokcen or not — and decided not to do it, just in case. They didn’t ask me. But if they ask, I thought, I’ll say…

‘On the other hand,’ Tim continued, ‘numismatists are not so wrong. Elagabalus said that his black Stone is both the Sun and Jupiter. This young emperor was, if you will, the Roman Akhenaten. Only he did not reject the other gods, but as if he tried to unite them all in one.’
I looked at the coin again.
‘And why are there mushrooms around the chariot? Was it a psychedelic cult?’
Tim laughed.
‘It’s amazing,’ he said, ‘that’s what young brains can do. You are on the threshold of a great historical discovery.’
‘Is it something else?’
‘None of the scientists knows for sure. But it’s funny about mushrooms. It wouldn’t have occurred to me.’
‘I don’t really understand,’ I said, ‘what’s funny here.’

‘There is a serious controversy in historical science about these items,’ Tim replied. ‘They say that these are umbrellas to protect against the summer heat, the religious procession was arranged on the day of the summer solstice, it was hot and… Others object that for purely theological reasons, the procession of the solar god could not hide from the deity to whom it was dedicated, and these are religious standards. Like the eagles of the heavenly legions… But about mushrooms, of course, the freshest idea. And what do you say about the emperor? Turn it over, he’s on the other side.’
‘Handsome one,’ I said.
‘And very young. He was sixteen or seventeen at the time.’
‘And who drives the chariot?’ I asked, looking at the coin. ‘There’s only this stone.’

‘That’s the point. During these processions, the reins of the horses were tied to a stone — there were actually six of them, by the way, there was simply not enough space on the coin. It was as if the solar god himself ruled. The young emperor held only one horse by the reins, and ran in front of the chariot backward, facing his god. On the road, they made markings out of gold powder, such as a central line so that he could navigate without turning around… On the day of the summer solstice, he ran across Rome to an altar built in the suburbs, and, having delivered his god there, offered sacrifices to him on many altars. It was a huge event, a national holiday. There were tall wooden towers around the altars, from which money and gifts were thrown to the people… and then the emperor danced in front of the stone, as before in the Emesa temple. Only it was no longer the soldiers who looked at him, but the entire Senate and the Roman people. In general, it was a unique period of history — several years when a huge powerful empire was ruled mainly with the help of dance. After that, the so-called Crisis of the Third Century began, and Rome never really recovered.’
‘What happened to the boy?’ I asked.

‘Naturally, he died. He was killed at the age of eighteen. And then his memory was cursed through the standard Roman proceduredamnatio memoriae. Before that, Caracalla had done the same with his brother Geta. Even the faces on the frescoes were removed. Quite a few are known about Elagabalus today. All traces of him have been destroyed. There were tendentious notes of senators-historians who hated him, where he is accused of all mortal sins, a couple of busts and these coins that are still being found.’
‘Why was he killed?’

‘And why was Caracalla or Commodus killed? Every emperor creates a hundred reasons for his death every day. It is not difficult to explain it in hindsight. No one asked “for what?”, when Caesar or Aurelian were killed.’
‘Caesar wanted to take away Rome’s freedom,’ I said, ‘and the free-spirited Brutus…’

‘Yeah. If Tiberius or Augustus had been killed, historians would also have found a lot of reasons. Officially, it is believed that Elagabal has lost the trust of the soldiers. They claim that he is mired in bliss, luxury and sophisticated forms of debauchery, which alienated the army from him, prone to more traditional forms of homosexuality. But that’s what they said about all the murdered emperors. They all turned out to be bad for some reason. It was not this, of course, that ruined him, but the fact that he left his enchanted Eastern legions and moved to Rome. The emperors were already appointed by the Praetorians at this time.’
‘Yes,’ I said, ‘I remember. Frank told that the emperors did not live in Rome for long.’
‘It’s true. Especially the late ones.’
‘What happened to the black stone?’

‘Elagabalus built a temple for him in Rome. He moved many famous ancient statues there to surround his deity with an honor guard. When the young emperor was killed, the statues were returned without much fanfare. The same thing happened with the black stone itself. It was returned to Syria, to the same temple in Emesa. There is a late coin of the minor Syrian usurper Uranus, who was also a Roman, where this stone is shown standing in its former place in the temple. And these, as you put it, mushrooms are hanging around again…’
‘And then? Where did the stone go then?’
Tim looked at me slyly.

‘History is silent about this. Scientists believe that the stone of Elagabalus was most likely broken into pieces by Christians in the fifth or sixth century. But no written evidence has been preserved.’
‘Where are its fragments now?’
‘I’m telling you, there is no scientific information on this.’
‘It feels,’ I said, ‘like you have unscientific ones.’
He grinned. In his grin, as if in a suitcase with contraband, a distinct second bottom shone through. Only then did I guess. And I was immediately amazed at how long it took me to do this.
‘Do you have the Stone?’
‘Maybe…’
‘No need to twist. You either have it or you don’t. What is the”maybe” can be here?’
‘Maybe,’ Tim said, ‘it’s not I who have it. Maybe, the Stone has me.’
He reached into the same drawer from which he had taken out the coin before, took out a small remote control and pressed a button.

The leather-sheathed wall behind his desk began to slowly rise, revealing the second half of the cabin, the existence of which was hinted at from the very beginning by the porthole divided in two. A soft light came on, and I saw a huge conical stone standing on a green velvet pedestal.

It was a deep black color with, smooth and rounded shape. I did not notice any chips or traces of clipping from a larger stone mass on it. For some reason, it immediately reminded me of the bottom half of a large hourglass. It was as if the time they were measuring had ended so long ago that the sand that had flowed into the lower cone had baked into a black mass, and the glass had crumbled and flown around…

On the side of the stone turned towards me there was an almost regular round spot, as if a fire had been splashed there, and a barely noticeable crater with traces of flying fragments was formed. The spot was surrounded by indistinct radial rays.
‘What is this spot?’

‘Some people, when they see it for the first time, remember about the Masons. The stone is triangular, and the spot resembles an eye. But those who worshipped Elagabal in ancient times said that it was a self-portrait of the Sun. Doesn’t it look like a picture of the crown during an eclipse?’
I nodded.
‘What came to your mind when you saw the stone?’ Tim asked.
‘An hourglass,’ I replied.
‘Interesting,’ Tim chuckled, looking at the stone. ‘Very interesting. I like it a lot more than what millennials usually say.’
‘What do they say?’
‘Frank said it was a landing capsule with a porthole. He assumed there was a dead alien inside.’
‘It looks a bit like that,’ I agreed. ‘Only the capsule is not big enough for a humanoid. Maybe a couple of extraterrestrial dogs.’

‘You should talk and think about the stone with reverence,’ Tim interrupted me, ‘for five whole years it was the main object of worship of the Roman Empire, that is, of the entire civilized world of that time. The decline of Rome began precisely when this shrine was returned to the East.’
‘What happened?’

‘Parthia attacked the Empire. Well, or Persia, as it is now called. Like if a stone returning to its temple in Emesa, began to gather a huge Eastern army to take revenge… then there was nothing good in Rome. It happened… How to put it in modern language, a reboot of reality.’
‘Do you believe that it happened because of the stone?’
Tim shrugged.
‘I don’t believe it,’ he said. ‘I know it.’
‘Where was the Stone the rest of the time?’
‘It’s not advertised.’
I realized that it’s better not to ask about the details.
‘Can you control it?’
‘This is not how it happens. The stone shows its power by itself. When the right person approaches it.’
‘In what sense is it suitable?’

‘In any sense. In any sense that works. There are people in the world who are able to turn the stone on, as it were. Having met them, the stone comes to life, and gives them power and direction. Frank was one of those people.’
‘I don’t think the stone gave him power,’ I said. ‘Rather, it drove him to insanity.’
‘I agree,’ Tim replied. ‘What happened is terrible. But if you had seen Frank before meeting the stone, you would have realized what an incredible transformation it was.’
‘What happens to a stone when it meets the right person?’
‘Changes do not happen to the stone, but to people. The echo of antiquity begins to sound in them. It’s like a reflection of the past in the present.’
‘Frank was talking about the same thing,’ I said. ‘About the echo of antiquity. But why did he go to Harran if he knew what had happened to Caracalla?’

‘Probably some power forced him to approach the fire that eventually burned him. There are secrets so great that people pay with their lives for touching them. But this is not the main thing that the stone is capable of.’
‘And what is the main thing?’

‘What happens when a stone meets a person who in ancient times was called the wordsoltator. This is the one who can control the entire power of the stone. It is enough to completely change our world.’
‘And how does soltator do it?’
‘With the help of dance. That’s the kind of person we’re looking for.’
‘And how to find him?’
‘The Stone must summon him itself.’
‘How does he do it?’
‘In different ways,’ Tim said. ‘But they usually approach the stone through the masks of Caracalla.’
‘Did Caracalla also control the stone?’
‘No. Never even tried. Even though he had all the family rights for that…’
‘Each mask has a black stone in a frame on its forehead. Are these shards?’
‘Yes. There’s a place down there where they split off from.’
I remembered the first time I put on a Moon mask in a hotel room. Frank didn’t ask me to do that. He just left the mask in plain sight. I wanted to do it myself.
‘Could Frank control the stone?’

‘Frank was visiting me on a yacht with friends. One day he came into my office and saw a Sun mask on the table. And immediately put it on, without even asking permission. Then I introduced him to the Stone. The Stone accepted him, and the masks passed to him… You know the rest.’
I nodded.
‘Now it’s your turn to touch the Stone,’ Tim said.
‘And what will happen?’
‘I don’t know. Maybe you’ll feel something. Or maybe you won’t feel anything. Everything will happen after. Do not be afraid…’
‘I’m not afraid,’ I replied. ‘Just touch? With a finger?’
Tim closed his eyes and for a few seconds put his palm to the recess in the stone, the ‘self-portrait of the Sun,’ as he called it. His fingers just fit into the uneven stone circle.
‘That’s it,’ he said, stepping aside.
I walked over to the stone and put my palm there as well.
The stone was warm. And it seemed to me that it was trembling a little. It was most likely the vibration of the yacht’s hull that passed through it, or my imagination.
Nothing seems to have happened.
However, lowering my hand, I already knew that now this piece of baked basalt had turned into a Stone with a capital letter for me.
‘It’s warm,’ I said. ‘Where did it come from anyway? I mean, before I got into Emesa?’
‘It is believed that it is a meteorite. Just an ancient meteorite. But there are other opinions about its nature.’
‘Which ones?’
‘Gradually you will find out.’
‘Was it worshipped before? Before Rome and Syria?’

‘It was, for example, a secret relic of the cult of the Sun under Akhenaten… Interestingly, the memory of all the events and historical figures associated with the Stone, then appeared to be destroyed.’
‘And why did the Stone make Frank a Caracalla? He’s been him in past lives?’

‘I don’t know,’ Tim said, ‘maybe it’s because they were similar. The Emesa Stone doesn’t just have tremendous power. It’s kind of charged with the history. It served as the magical center of the world at the peak of Roman power, at a time when magic was a real and universally recognized state power. It oozes with the past and seems to be trying to repeat its fragments. To reproduce some ancient mystery… A kind of eternal return.’
‘Return to what?’
Tim spread his hands.

‘There are people whom the Stone takes into its retinue,’ he said. ‘There are few of them, but somehow they find their way to it. If the Stone accepts you, it sort of assigns you a role. Frank became Caracalla, and the spirit of Caracalla spoke through him. You were… I don’t know, the Moon goddess from Carrhae? Or her priestess?’
‘A little bit of everything,’ I said.
‘I think that you are a kind of magnet, able to attract those who are looking for a Stone. You have to find a new Elagabalus.’
‘But why me?’
Tim smiled.

‘Opposites are drawn to each other. You have attracted Frank, as the goddess of the Moon once attracted Caracalla. Soltator will come to you in the same way. Sooner or later it will happen. And you will lead him to the Stone.’
Probably, touching the ancient shrine has already worked. Tim’s strange words did not cause me to protest. I understood the logic of what he was saying.
‘But how am I going to look for him?’ I asked.
‘Frank said you know.’
I grinned.
‘Actually, I do. I have a method. But I’m not sure it will work here.’

‘You’re going to have masks,’ Tim said. ‘The stone and the masks are one. Therefore, the Sun Stone will be with you all the time. If you want to talk to him, go to sleep with a mask on. Now that the Stone has accepted you, it will work.’
‘Which one? There are two of them.’
‘I don’t know,’ Tim said. ‘Try to experiment.’
The three of us had dinner.

Young people were having fun in the anarchist salon — music, voices and the smell of weed could be heard from there, which even the mighty ventilation could not cope with. It was possible to visit the fighters exhausted in the battle with the digital Goolag. Although they will certainly ask about what happened…
So understood what I was thinking.
‘I’ll warn the guys not to talk about Frank. I’ll say it’s your trigger. That’s how it gets to them.’
‘Thank you, but I don’t want to see anyone. I’m going to bed.’
Returning to my cabin, I undressed, sat on the bed and put the masks in front of me.

p.emphasis: Lovely moonchild, dreaming in the shadow of the willow…

section.p: Strangely, the masks no longer reminded me of Frank. Now they were just two beautiful ancient faces looking at me from the abyss of the past.

What did Nietzsche say? If you look into the abyss for a long time, then the abyss will start looking at you. He wasn’t lying: the abyss was already staring at me with four oblong green eyes. For some reason, it had eyes the same color as the bedspread.
I thought that if I put on one of the masks and lay on my back, it is quite possible to sleep all night in it.

I’ve already fallen asleep a couple of times in a moon mask when Frank was around, though not for long. I didn’t remember any vivid dreams, although several times it seemed to me that I could almost see what Frank was talking about.
But at that time I hadn’t been introduced to the Stone yet — maybe that’s the point? Or should I have fallen asleep in a mask of the Sun?
Now we’ll find out, I thought.

p.emphasis: Emoji of a cute blonde going to bed in a spiked mask of the Sun behind the rays of which it is not even visible that she is a blonde, which is not so scary because the night is dark, empty and deserted and there are not many to impress in it.png

section.p: The ornate marble staircase that arched down looked very old. The wide steps were twice as high as usual, as if it was built for giants or gods. It’s good that I was coming down.
I’ve never seen anything like this in any palace before. Polished stone, carved flowers, faces of Helios and Selena. I couldn’t imagine who built it and when.
And, most importantly, where.
Out of fear, I repeated to myself an ancient prayer that Gannys had once taught me:
‘Many-faced and Invisible, let me into the hall of mystery… Many-faced and Invisible, let me into the hall of mystery…’

It was necessary to pray like this for hours, and I often repeated these words at night in order to fall asleep faster… Oh the horror, it occurred to me — what if god heard and really let me into the hall? And what am I going to do in it now?
