The stairs descended in circles into the darkness, and I walked along them, sometimes entering the light of torches, sometimes diving into the darkness.

After each circle there was a platform where was a marble statue of a lion-headed man entwined with snakes. Torches and oil lamps were burning on the wall behind him, so that the lionhead could be clearly seen.

The lion’s mouth was red on the inside and looked menacing. The snake’s head was lying on the lion’s, as if not letting the mouth open to the end — and the snake was biting the tip of its own tail… In symbolic language, it meant something, but what? I knew before, but I forgot.
Probably because of these snake heads, it seemed to me that I was running down the rings of a huge snake hanging down into the eternal night.

Soon I noticed that the platforms I walk through are different from each other. Lion-headed statues were the same everywhere. But in front of each stood a marble pedestal with a sacred bronze object. And these items were different on each platform. Realizing this, I began to closely monitor what floats out of the darkness to meet me.
First, there was a crow — a little funny, proudly spreading its wings, the span of which was still not enough to pass for an eagle.
A flight below on the pedestal laid a tiara like a royal one, only not made of gold, but bronze.
Even lower was the breastplate of a military armor, a real one, with traces of blows. It looked very old: Odysseus or Achilles must have worn such armor.
Even lower was a laurel wreath, which I took at first for another tiara. But the wreath was bigger and wider. If someone puts on these bronze laurels, he should have a strong neck.
Below was a sword with a hook extending from the blade to the side — such, I remembered, were in use among pirates.
Next was the Helios mask with spikes-like rays. I thought, it could’ve been worn by a circus gladiator.
Even lower was a large bowl with a pimpled bottom.
Then the crow appeared again, and everything began to repeat itself: a tiara, a shell, a wreath, a sword, a mask and a bowl. And then the crow again.
I decided that the same symbols, copied with great accuracy, appear every seven floors. But then I noticed a deep scratch on one of the crow’s wings, glistening in the lamplight, and I remembered it.
A scratch of the same shape and depth was on the wing of each of the bronze birds.

Moreover, there was a thin metal burr next to the scratch, which seemed to have been left by a sword or spear blow, and it also repeated without changes. Either someone who passed here before me beat another bronze crow with the same weapon with the same force every seven floors, which was impossible, or…
Either it’s the same crow, and I’m wandering around the ring in the dark.

There would be nothing surprising in such a thing if I was walking down the corridor. Or at least went down some stairs and up others. But I kept going down, as if running down an endless Archimedean screw.
And yet every seven torchlit flights I found myself in the same place.
It wasn’t just the crow. I noticed other recurring details: potholes and stains on the marble, the location of the torches themselves, the characteristic patterns of the stone.

Going down the stairs, I walked around the circle. It couldn’t have been that way, of course. But philosophers, I remembered, call it logic: an indisputable conclusion has to be accepted, even when it contradicts the usual experience.

Why am I going down? What do I want to find there? I thought about it, and a feeling of horror came into my heart. I remembered that this is a dream that foreshadows death — an endless descent down the stairs into darkness…
Is this a dream?
But I was not sleeping — I pinched myself and did not wake up; I felt the bitter smell of torches and the cold touch of marble. My senses were sharper than ever.
Maybe I was killed — and I’m descending to Hades?

And suddenly I remembered the news that came from Carrhae a day ago. The emperor, who was my distant relative, as they thought in Rome and Syria, but actually my own father, was killed during the military campaign.
When the emperor is killed, his family does not have long to live. The faces of the household were grim and determined. Even the women were preparing for death.

For the first time I saw what the last toy of a noble lady looks like — a precious vial of poison, a tiny sarcophagus of Cleopatra, entwined with transparent snakes, a miracle of jewelry carving, black from a terrifying filling. I have also seen sharp Syrian razors for opening veins. These secret objects, stored up for the last hour, were now lying in plain sight in our house, next to the couches where food was taken.
Then… Then something happened and I ended up here.

My spirit was calm. If I’m dead, there’s nothing to grieve about. But where are the souls of the other dead? Where is Styx, where is Charon’s boat? Or does this staircase lead me to them and I will run down it until I forget my entire former life to the last detail?
I once heard a serious adult debate on this topic: the soul, in order to merge with the World Spirit, must first lose everything that makes it special and different from others, said one disputant.

But what’s the use of sea-worn pebbles, another objected, if there are many of them on the shore and they are all just one stone repeated many times? Why does such a spirit can be needed and to whom? The spirit does not have to be needed by someone, the first one answered, you will know the rest when you die… After death there is no memory and there is no horror.

I really didn’t feel any horror. Rather it was interesting: How will I forget myself? Will it hurt? Maybe the bronze sword I’m passing by will suddenly fall off the stand and cut off my head? Or will I just grow old during the endless journey down and the memory will imperceptibly pour out of me like a grain from a leaky bag?
No, I realized after a few more laps, that’s not how it’s going to happen.

I will look at the bronze crow, then at this wreath, then at this mask of the Sun, and there will be no reason to remember anything else. After all, I have not been thinking about my past life for a long time, but am completely absorbed in my strange journey. I’m wary of watching what’s around me and noticing the changes that are taking place.
Someone is changing burnt-out torches for new ones. They are the same, but longer and sit in rings a little differently. Someone is adding oil to the lamps.

Maybe there are scaffoldings hidden in the darkness around, where invisible slaves hide, like those who serve the arena? When I leave from one platform to another, they silently jump down on it and prepare it for my next pass…

Some huge and hidden mechanism in the darkness constantly carries the segments of the staircase I have passed down and silently connects them with the rest. Meanwhile, the section I’m going down is moving smoothly upwards, and the whole structure, connected to invisible machines, remains in place.… Imagining this, I felt dizzy and almost stumbled.
Such mechanics are probably difficult to hide even in the largest building. Moreover, its work will depend on the speed of my downward movement.
But... why am I going down?

The answer was, of course, simple — everyone knows that going downstairs is easier than going up. But if my guess about the mechanism is correct, it’s enough for me to go up so that its work becomes visible… For some reason, it seemed to me that this idea was given to me by a bronze crow.

If I was really descending into Hades, I thought, his spirits might not like me climbing back to life. But the spirits have not yet manifested themselves in any way, except for the change of torches and lamps. And this could just as well be done by people.
There will be a bowl now. Then the crow again — and she will probably look with contempt at the coward who failed to take advantage of her advice…
Suddenly even for myself, I turned around and went up the middle of another staircase.

The platform was in place. A lion-headed man with a red mouth, just seen, floated by — he looked at me indifferently with his whitish marble eyes. On the pedestal in front of him lay the same Sun mask with spikes as a minute ago. Nothing has changed.
But the next circle of steps looked darker than usual. And soon I realized why.
There was no platform at the end of it.
The staircase ended in a black void, and I froze in fright at its edge.

The fright, however, quickly passed. A breeze was flying out of the darkness, warm and fresh, as if I was standing over the night sea. Nothing was visible, but it seemed to me that in front of me was the primordial abyss, where the gods and the world were once born. Here the darkness is only for me, and for the gods everything is flooded with light.

The gods soar in this light and indulge in pleasures that are not understandable to a mortal. Maybe one of those pleasures is watching us. Maybe what the sages call Chaos is also one of their games — the sweetest one… Or are the wise Greeks right when they say that our earthly life is a shameful mistake and it is wisest to return to where we came from as soon as possible?

There was movement in the darkness. I don’t know what alerted me — a barely noticeable sound or a puff of wind… I backed up the steps and saw a rock soundlessly approaching, like a huge stone jaw slanting down from above. A moment later, a new platform with a lion-headed statue, illuminated by the trembling lights of lamps and torches, connected with a barely audible knock to the stairs.
Yes, everything was as I assumed. I didn’t seem to have heard this stone knocking before… or did I hear it, but didn’t attach any importance to it? After all, I heard some sounds. Or I didn’t?
Maybe I’m dreaming after all? A dream can be incredibly convincing, because it relies only on itself for its confirmation. We need to check the sequence of bronze symbols.
The mask of the Sun remained below. So, there should be a sword with a hook on the platform that descended from the darkness. I went up the stairs again, but I didn’t get to the end of it.
On the edge of the platform stood a warrior who looked like a fighter from some terrible afterlife circus.

Thinking about it, I immediately realized that any arena, from the Flavian amphitheater to the lists of Emesa, is an afterlife circus. On the one hand, it is earthly, and ordinary people come there, and on the other, it is otherworldly and surrounded by hungry spirits… The shadows of the deceased are also looking for circuses and feeding on shed blood.
This thought flashed through my mind in the shortest moment, and I was even surprised that I had never thought about such a thing. And then the fear came.
The light falling on the warrior was enough to get a good look at him.

In his right hand was the same sword with a hook, which I was going to look at a couple of minutes ago. On the chest was a bronze plate bent by blows. In his left hand was a small convex shield, in which I recognized a bronze bowl… it looks like he armed himself with sacred objects by walking along the same stairs where I had walked before.
He was also wearing a dark helmet in the form of a bull’s head — quite common among circus gladiators and therefore not too frightening to me.
But the helmet was made with amazing skill. That’s what I thought at first — and then, when the small, menacingly sparkling eyes blinked several times, I realized that it wasn’t a helmet.

It was a live bull’s head, at the same time scary and funny because of the bronze wreath slanted on it… Above me stood a Cretan horror, the Minotaur, exactly like the one on the mosaic from our house in Emesa. And the second I recognized him, he slowly walked down the stairs toward me.

I ran away. But there was no other staircase beyond the lower landing — it ended in emptiness. I either broke the rhythm of the stone wheel in which I was running, or I got out of it myself… Even if a new ladder appears out of the darkness in a minute or two, it will be too late: the bull-headed fighter will overtake me before.

Is it really a Minotaur? Perhaps I myself summoned him from the world of shadows, remembering about the mosaic? After all, they say in Rome, if a person who gets lost in the forest is afraid of a wolf, it will feel the fear and come… Or did the Minotaur appear before my fear?
You can’t understand it now.

He descended the stairs slowly and confidently, and seemed to dance with every step, ringing with his abundant bronze. It rattled like that, but he also struck a small shield with his sword, as barbarians do before a battle.
Who is he, a man? Or a beast? He holds his weapon like a warrior. But there is something bestial in his manner. No, he doesn’t look like a man. At least not someone like me.
I can’t beat him, I thought, no matter how hard I fight. But I can scare him… all animals are afraid of fire.

He had already passed half of the steps separating us. I backed away, returned to the lion-headed statue, tore the torch from the wall and waved it wide over my head several times. The Minotaur shielded his eyes with his shield. He didn’t like the light too much.
But he wasn’t scared. On the contrary, he lowered his sword, let out a long cry, midway between a groan and a moo, and kept his descent.
And then the bronze bird appeared in my mind’s eye again, which this bull has not yet made part of his ammunition. The crow, I remembered, had once given advice to Mithra.

He’s not a beast or a man, the crow said silently. He is something in between, and is like a small child killing while playing. The Minotaur is not afraid of fire. He knows what it is. He is only afraid of the unknown…
And then I realized that I had one last chance to scare him. Raising the torch above my head, I backed away, and took the mask of the Sun from the marble pedestal.

When I looked at the Minotaur through the bronze eye sockets, he stopped, puzzled. I must have looked unusual in a crown of bronze rays — but did I inspire fear? I probably should have waved my arms and shouted, as they do when driving away an animal… or not? The bull, they say, attacks the one who tries to scare him…
Dance, said the crow.
There was no crow nearby, but the same thing happened every time. At first I saw her image, and then the thought she communicated appeared in my mind.
Dance.
That’s right. The bull, or who is he, hardly afraid of my threats and screams. But he may be puzzled by something strange. Pantomime. Dance…

It seemed to me that I could hear the light and fast playing of several flutes and a tambourine. It was one of those ancient Hellenic melodies that treat spider bites and fever, they are often heard in cities on holidays.
I’m not sure if the music was actually playing. But, real or not, it sounded clear to me, and I started dancing without delay.

After a couple of jumps, I realized that the soft protrusion of the mask that pokes my nose is leather straps, and it’s not necessary to hold it in your hand in front of your face, but you can just put it on your head. It was held securely and firmly.
My dance could not stop the bull completely, but it delayed him, as if entangling him in a net: the faster I danced, the slower the monster was coming.

I don’t really remember exactly how I waved my arms and legs, jumped and squatted. It seems that I was moving from one side of the platform to the other, as if trying to draw a line with my movements, beyond which the minotaur could not go — but he still went beyond it, and suddenly with one poke of his huge hand knocked down a marble statue.
Fortunately, by this time the landing was connected to another staircase and I had somewhere to retreat.
It became easier to go down: the voids between the stairs disappeared, and it was enough for me to dance all the time to keep the bull from attacking.

All the platforms now bore the mark of the monster that had passed here: statues with red mouths were toppled and smashed. But then I got to the platform, where the statue entangled with snakes stood exactly the same as before.
In the light of the torches in front of him, a bronze crow opened her wings and glittered green and yellow.
‘Defeat him,’ said the crow. ‘You can win. You can.’
Her bronze beak didn’t move, but I could have sworn I heard those words.
‘How?’
‘Just dance it. Dance his death… and then he will disappear.’
‘But I don’t know how!’
‘Then call someone who knows…’
Immediately after these words, the crow took off and flew away into the darkness.
Unfortunately, not by herself — she was overtaken by a powerful blow. I was distracted for a few seconds, and that was enough for the Minotaur to be there.
Fortunately, first he unleashed his rage on the statue, and I managed to retreat.
I understood what the crow wanted to say.
The dancer always adapts to the world staring at him, trying to please it. I danced for the bull.
But that was the mistake — Minotaur was not an observer. He was part of my dance. I should have danced his doom for the whole world, as if people and gods were looking at me from the darkness.
I’ve heard this before. I was taught this, taught for a long time… How would I feel if I beat Minotaur? Joy. Easement. Pride. Delight.
When, having finished with the statue, the bull turned to me, I was not afraid. I’ve already remembered the secret.
Dancing, I went at him, not threatening, not trying to scare him, no. I went into the void, where there was no bull — and he obediently backed away. But then he stopped.
And then I remembered who I should call. I raised my bronze face and shouted into the darkness:
‘Elagabal! Elagabal! Elagabal!’
I was expecting a bright light to flash. Sunlight. But something completely different happened.
Frightened by my unexpected cry, the bull shied back — and fell into the darkness, falling off the edge of the platform.

Everything happened easily and naturally, as if it was part of the dance. Or rather, it really became a part of it: the Minotaur had to dance it with me, and that was his role. I wasn’t even surprised by my victory.
The crow was right. In simple words, she gave me a great secret and wisdom. When I was taught this, I didn’t understand. Now I understood.
I turned and ran up the stairs.

After running through several platforms, I ran into a void, like the last time. But now I didn’t stop. I decided to dance a world where beyond this black abyss there will be another staircase, invisible and leading home. And, running to the edge of the platform, I jumped into the void and shouted:
‘Elagabal!’
It really flashed in front of my eyes.

But it happened because I hit my forehead against an invisible wall that sounded like a gong. It seems that I broke through or knocked over some kind of barrier. I realized that I had lost my balance and was falling.
But I did not fall into the abyss, but onto the soft floor, hitting it unpleasantly with my elbow. After waiting for a little, I decided to open my eyes.

Above me was a tall ebony chair with unraveled leather laces on the arms. My hands hurt. Lamps and torches were burning on the wall. And next to me, on the soft animal skins, there was an overturned bronze mirror in a wooden frame, on which I had just hit my head.
There was a lion-headed statue against the wall, the same shape as in my dream, but three times smaller in size.

I knew this room. It was the basement of our house in Emesa. A round room where wine was poured from amphorae. Only, tiger skins have never been laid here before. And I didn’t see any mirrors here either.
There was a stone staircase leading up toward the exit. An ordinary oak door with a ring instead of a handle, which I have opened many times. I went up the stairs, pushed the door, and it opened.
There were people behind it. My grandmother Maesa. My teacher Gannys. And my tearful mother.
I’ve never seen Gannys so excited.
‘Varius,’ he said. ‘We heard you calling for god. And he heard you. You’re back, my boy. Well done. I knew thatsoltator was you.’
It was already morning, I could feel the sunlight around me, but something prevented me from opening my eyes. I raised my hand to my face, and my fingers touched the metal.
I slept all night in a mask of the Sun.

I remembered my dream as clearly as I remembered the movie I watched five times. There was just one important difference — I didn’t watch this movie, but I lived through it. I seriously descended into Hades, then trembled with fear and was filled with victorious glee.

And also in a dream I was a boy, still quite small by our modern standards, and experienced his thoughts as my own. I knew now what it was like to think like a boy. However, to be honest, I knew it before, and even had some practical experience.

The other thing was amazing: I not only ran along the stairs dissolving in the dark from someone else’s dream, but also remembered someone’s life as my own. But I didn’t remember anything about mine in this dream. I was a different person one hundred percent.
I felt a slight smell of weed and understood why I was visited by the idea of gender. Somewhere nearby, despite the early hour, a progressive revolution was already being prepared.

Yesterday I absolutely did not want to look at corporate anarchists. But today I needed to eat up my night experience with something earthy and textured, and make sure that I surfaced into a modern, reliable, understandable world.

I put on the yellow uniform robe that was hanging in the bathroom. It had only one shoulder strap and one medal, which apparently indicated a low rank in the local hierarchy. But still, I hoped that it gave me the right to move around the ship.

I was already able to navigate around the yacht, but even if I lost my way, I could find it by the characteristic smell. I remembered a joke: the cops ring the doorbell and say — the neighbors complain, you have laughter here all night and it smells like burnt rags. What’s happening? Oh, nothing, the tenants answer, it’s just we burn rags and laugh…
I walked down the corridor, went down the stairs and opened the door to the anarchist headquarters. ‘And here’s Sasha,’ So said in Russian.

There were three of my old acquaintances here — Michael, his sister Sarah and Michael’s boyfriend Rajiv, who during my absence had dyed his beard with henna and finally looked like an ancient Indian strangler in the moonlight. Sarah has hardly changed, only her hedgehog has grown and become darker. As for Michael, he was at that stage of bespectacled beardness, when no noticeable changes at all occur with a person.

Besides them, two other people were sitting on pillows — a guy and a girl. The guy was older than me, and the girl was much younger. The last observation was not very pleasant, and I thought that the patriarchy could get out of my head at least now.
I recognized the compatriots and guessed that they had spent the night on the yacht — it was still too early for visits. Apparently, So picked them up somewhere in Istanbul, just like me.

The guy looked like a very fat Kerensky — he had the same mop-like hedgehog and the face of a church singer, molested first by priests, and then by ghosts of Communism roaming around Europe. He was associated with modernity by a black T-shirt with a red inscription “VIVA PUCE”[5]. It was the first time I saw Latin letters written in Slavic script. It looked interesting.
The girl was very fair-skinned, with a real blond braid. She looked like a duck. In a good way — it was clear that she would take care of his ducklings and protect them from any goose.
I didn’t recognize them by their clothes or even by their faces, but by the way they reacted to the Russian speech — they tensed up a little.
I didn’t get the feeling that they were glad to meet a compatriot. However, I didn’t feel much joy either. It was an eternal and repeatedly described phenomenon of “meeting Russians abroad”.
‘Hi, Sasha,’ said the guy. ‘Nice to meet you. I’m Alexey.’
‘Sasha,’ I replied sourly.
‘Tamara,’ the girl introduced herself. ‘Don’t show off, please, Alyosha.’
‘Nothing,’ I said in Russian. ‘That’s interesting, by the way. Why do Russians abroad avoid each other and try not to speak Russian?’
‘Can you speak English?’ Michael asked, ‘Because it seems to us that you are conspiring against our democracy.’
I repeated it in English.
‘This,’ said Alexey, ‘easily lends itself to understanding.’

He spoke English a little intricately, but with perfect pronunciation. It seemed that he had a whole staff of dusty men and women working in his head, offering variants of formulations. I imagined them lifting phrases hastily written on cardboard boxes above their heads, and Alexey was intently reading them out. However, this is how the subconscious mind works, I thought.
‘And what is the reason?’ I asked.
‘The fact is,’ Alexey replied, ‘that in the historical aspect somewhere from the thirteenth century, when happened the Mongol… mmm…’
‘Yoke,’ I prompted.
He looked at me disapprovingly.

‘Genocide. Since that time, it has become dangerous to be among foreigners in a group of Russian-speaking people. This meant that most probably you would be killed very soon. Together with the whole group. A kind of scar appeared on the collective unconscious. Therefore, a Russian escaping abroad, at the first opportunity, seeks to join a safe and protected community of people who speak English.’
‘Why would they kill you?’ Michael asked.
‘Are you familiar with Russian history?’
Michael shrugged.

‘You know,’ Alexey continued, ‘I’ve been reading in the news here recently, either in Ryazan, or in Yaroslavl, these are cities built in the Middle Ages, the basement of an old house was accidentally dug out. Thirteenth or fourteenth century. It was filled to the brim with children’s and women’s corpses. The whole basement. Wounds from swords and arrows, the work of professional warriors. Mongol horde, in a word. The most common Russian discovery. The dead were not even taken out and buried… Maybe no one knew, because there were no living witnesses left. They just leveled the fire and built anew from above.’
‘What does Russian history have to do with it?’

‘That’s what. Our whole history is such a charred basement with corpses, a non-stop genocide, on which from time to time some Marquis de Custine comes to urinate, completely unafraid that a bony dead hand will rise from the ashes and grab him by the balls. And do you know why?’
‘Why?’

‘Since the time of the Mongols, Russia has been ruled by the organizers and beneficiaries of these corpse cellars. And more than anything, they want to be friends with the Marquis de Custine. Because cultural leisure in Paris, the south of France and all in general.’
‘Well, yes,’ I said, ‘there is such a thing. But that’s not our whole history.’

‘All of it. Even the word “slave” comes from the Latin “Slav”. It meant a Slavic prisoner — the eighth or tenth century, the raids of the Holy Roman Empire, the huge masses of civilians captured in slavery. This is before the Mongols. We were Negroes before it became fashionable — Slavic slaves were valued in Western Europe as highly as Slavic wives are today. But no one even comes close to an idea of reparations!’
‘These are not the Mongols that invaded back then,’ I said. ‘And we are not the Slavs who were slaves.’

‘Yeah. And why then write on the blackboard at school “we are not slaves”? Do they write in England? We weren’t just slaves. We have been slaves in the permanent mode for a significant part of our history. And we are still reaping the consequences. Guys, if you seriously want to repent for slavery and its consequences, you’re doing it the wrong way. The modern American Negro is a highly privileged being compared to the modern white Russian. And we constantly hear in the news about some kind of white privilege…’
‘And what are the conclusions?’ I asked, trying to steer the conversation away from a dangerous turn.

‘Conclusions? Any figure of Russian culture should fight for the recognition of the worldwide, and especially the Anglo-Saxon-German-French-Mongol-Latvian cultural and political guilt for our continuous genocide and historical slave status.’
‘And the blacks have also been guilty?’

‘Blacks are our natural companions in the fight against the white Western bloodsucker… Our message should be like this — black, brown, yellow, all people of color, we are your oppressed brothers, white niggas, and together we will tear apart the hypocritical Western elite, strangling you with systemic racism! We are being strangled together with you! The point is not whether political correctness is needed or not, the point is what its vector is. And this is the most important question, because in the twenty-first century, this is how the question of power will be solved!’
‘Do you have a different political correctness?’ Michael asked, listening attentively, ‘not like ours?’
‘For a time being the other,’ said Alexey. ‘Although the genesis is the same.’
‘What do you mean — the same in genesis?’ So asked.
By this time, a shadow of slight anxiety appeared on her face, like a hostess who noticed that a guest became drunk and was about to commit an outrage. But she was still smiling politely.

‘What is political correctness in general and why does it exist?’ Alexey asked the golden ear on the ceiling. ‘In your America, someone said that this is fascism posing as good manners. But it is easier to explain it to a Russian person in another way. We have a gang of ghouls who inherited the country from the Communists. And their power has about the same nature as the power of the Communists — that is, it relies solely on the fact that it has been seized by force. Together with the rights of large property, by the way. And now ghouls reproduce all this with the help of various technologies, power and information…’
‘These ghouls outrage you,’ Michael put in.

‘I am outraged not that they are ghouls,’ Alexey replied, ‘but that they are also morons. To legitimize their heist, they seem to say — yes, we stole the whole Gulag, but we are educating you. We take care of your health, mental and physical. We explain how you should live, and we will be whipping you until you learn. Therefore, there is no way without us, we are in the center of a cyclone and we will suck your blood, damping oil price fluctuations with your corpses…’
This time it was hard not to agree with Alexey.
‘It’s true,’ I sighed. ‘That’s exactly what it is.’
‘What, in your opinion, is the main source of the world’s evil?’ So asked unexpectedly.
I would be stumped by such a question. But Alexey didn’t think for more than a second.

‘The main source of global evil is mass media. Factories that shape reality. They create a myth in which we live. So this is not just the main source of evil, it is its only legitimate source on the planet. No one else has either the right or the opportunity to designate things as good or evil. This is even more important than printing dollars.’
‘Are you saying that your media doesn’t do that?’

‘The world’s media cannot be compared with the Russian ones. You know, it’s like a mighty elephant going somewhere about his business, and a fussy little dog that runs between his legs, squeals, barks and sometimes stops to devour elephant shit. This, generally speaking, is the only food of it. There are news in America because there is politics there. Thank God, we have no politics — only intrigues in the single-party ministry of the court. There is no culture either, and thank God too, because it’s scary to think what it would be like. The Russian news is when the millennials compose a clickbait headline, hang it under a bloody video and attach three advertising blocks to it, which need to be filtered with their brains before they let them look at the blood…’
‘What, they don’t distinguish at all?’ Sarah asked.
‘Why, sometimes they distinguish. If they eat some shit beforehand.’
‘What shit?’

‘I told you. Elephant’s. In our media, you won’t believe it, they translate and quote all the articles that someone remembered about Russia. Even the blogs of unemployed African-American women. And if a couple of German gays write a song about Russia, then all the imperialists will hug and thankfully cry. Such a nationwide ego-surfing — a hungry bear jerks off in a den to his photos. Sometimes on caricatures too. Like, once they remembered, it means they’re still afraid…’

By this time, Alexey was reeking of some kind of absolutely killer psychic heat, like from a well-melted astral stove. His girlfriend barely nodded her head, the words of her boyfriend cradled and comforted her. It was time to go out, which I quietly did.

Where did So get this from… A powerful… native speaker. It was amazing, I thought, but this guy would surely have found a common ground with the late Frank. Why is this eerie reversal happening at the same time in such different and distant brains… Where to? To the right? No, it was in the last century. Some new mutations. They just haven’t found the right word yet.

However, getting into this ideological ray turned out to be healing. After all, I came here to find support — well, I found it. I gained the necessary ballast, made sure that the world around me is one hundred percent real. Even for all three hundred.
The main thing is that the wind blowing from the past will no longer knock me down on the deck. Because now it’s hard to say where from the wind is blowing stronger.

In the hallway, I remembered that a couple of days ago I received a long letter from Antosha, where he also wrote something about clickbait. I looked at it briefly, but now, marveling at such a synchronization, I wanted to get acquainted with his message in detail.
Antosha didn’t ask about anything. Didn’t ask where I was. But he talked a lot about himself. Firstly, he left the “Existential Abyss”. Secondly, he decided to devote himself entirely to literature.

Now he was no longer writing his endless Japanese monogatari, where I managed to become a frog, but an “absolutely innovative” novel about the struggle against evil clickbait media, which he called “Don’t Click the Fate.”
The innovation was that the whole novel consisted of those “clickbait headlines.”
The text, explained Antosha, is built on the same principle as “Eugene Onegin” or the Egyptian pyramids: blocks of the same size and shape gradually add up to a fascinating design with many meanings.
He even sent the first two pages in the appendix, which gave a “wide panorama of pre-crisis Russian life” (he had no doubt that there would be a crisis).

v.emphasis: 1.1 A St. Petersburg man invited a girl on a date and showed her a corpse.
1.2 Russians were offered to live in an iron barrel.
1.3 The black singer wrestled with the size of his penis with a sandwich.
1.4 The raccoon got drunk on mulled wine and died.
1.5 The Russian beat his wife and eight-month-old child with a bucket.
1.6 Instead of a surfer eaten by sharks, they found a diver eaten by them.
1.7 A Russian tortured his neighbors with a horse neighing.
1.8 A criminal on a pink scooter snatched a dildo from a Muscovite.
1.9 A Russian man beat a child because of his bad posture, decided to comfort him and strangled.
1.10 The inventor who dismembered the journalist married a native of Russia.
1.11 A lesbian taken to Azerbaijan told about life on a chain.
1.12 Evdokia the Hairy agreed to an intimate photoshoot.
1.13 The Russians who survived the bath party were called to the TV show and called morons.
1.14 The riddle of the origin of consciousness in the brain has been solved.
2.1 A young man brutally killed a pedophile priest with a cross.
2.2 The passenger of the plane annoyed the fellow traveler with her hair and was reputed to be vile.
2.3 A locksmith jumped out of a window after robbing, raping and murdering an old lady.
2.4 The man simulated the sounds of fireworks with his mouth and basin.
2.5 The thought of a mangy old woman did not help the Russian to stop ejaculation.
2.6 A woman found a skeleton in the forest and recognized her son in it.
2.7 The girl accidentally exposed herself in front of the man and made him blush.
2.8 A farmer got drunk and was eaten by giant pigs after a heart attack.
2.9 A Russian climbed onto the roof of a high-speed train, started a fire and died.
2.10 The monkey rushed at the woman hanging the laundry and killed her.
2.11 The disgusting activity of a barefoot air passenger angered fellow travelers and got on video.
2.12 A thong with rhinestones was found under the skirt of Maria Gender.
2.13 The conversation of the deceased at a bath party with sellers of dry ice is published.
2.14 Brain function was impossible to explain.

section.p: Well, yeah. You can’t drink away the misogyny. I shouldn’t have worried.

The main message of the novel, wrote Antosha, is that the global destruction of the media business and propaganda in its modern form is a necessary act of civil self-defense if humanity is seriously planning to survive. The news should be produced by a special kind of knightly orders that have yet to be formed.

The development was expected to be as follows: Russia will weaken, wandering in the Arabian sands and European tribunals, a crisis will begin, and then a certain party, originally organized by the regime for political clowning, will sweep away the tyrant along with his entire clique (meaning trolls who clicks the links) and the golden age will begin.
Then the news headlines will be as follows:

v.emphasis: N.1 A rooster got plucked instead of a chicken.
N.2 A barmaid who had eaten watermelon went to pee behind a booth.
N.3 A cat dozed off on a stack of boards.
N.4 A plantain grew between old sleepers.
N.5 On a foggy day the water pump is almost invisible from the river.
N.6 Someone prayed: "Good Lord!"

section.p: And so on. Quiet, calm, a little on budget — but no dark, grim, bloody clickbait stuff.
I do not know whether Antosha was being ironic or not, but I would’ve definitely moved to this new Russia from the existing one.
But so far I’ve been wandering around completely different places, and after five minutes I completely forgot about Antosh and clickbait. And ten minutes later I quietly fell asleep.

When I woke up, it was still daylight. I dozed off without a mask, but I still dreamed of marble stairs and lion-headed idols. However, no one jumped on the stairs anymore. Probably just an echo of the night trip.
The intercom beeped nearby — it woke me up.
‘Sasha,’ said So, ‘if you’re looking for us, we’re at Tim’s office.’
Probably, I thought, this is a polite way to hint that they want to see me.
A few minutes later, I knocked on the office door.
‘Come in.’

The partition dividing the cabin in half had been raised, and the Stone stood on the stand in all its ancient glory. In the light of day, it did not seem so streamlined — small irregularities and chips were visible. Battle scars. No earthly hero has such a biography, I thought.
‘The guests have already left,’ So said. ‘Right after lunch.’
I overslept the lunch.
‘Where did you find Alexey?’ I asked.
‘It’s not me,’ So smiled, ‘this is Rajiv. He brought them from some conference. Alexey thought there would be a meeting with American investors.’
‘And who is he anyway?’
‘Someone’s sixteenth referent on ideology. I don’t always understand these nuances of yours.’
‘Me too,’ I said. ‘What is he doing in Istanbul? What kind of conference?’
‘It’s just a trial of the political discourse. Maybe that’s what he was sent for.’

‘Yeah,’ I sighed. ‘The bastards sponsor a protest against the bastards and come to power on a wave of bastard’s anger. Even the plaques on the cabinets don’t need to be changed. I saw something similar in my dream today…’
‘What?’
‘A snake was biting its tail.’
‘A snake?’ Tim asked again. ‘Tell us more, please.’
‘She was wrapped around a marble lion… Or rather, a man with a lion’s head…’
And I told my dream about the stairs.
So and Tim listened very carefully.
‘That’s the only important thing,’ Tim said. ‘Do you know who this boy is?’
‘I guess,’ I replied. ‘This is Soltator. That’s what they called him.’
‘This is Elagabalus, the future emperor of Rome.’
I nodded.
‘If you saw it, then the Stone accepted you,’ So said. ‘Did you sleep in a sun mask?’
‘Yes. Is that right?’
‘As you wish,’ Tim answered, ‘If the Stone has started talking to you, any of the masks would work fine. But there is a difference between the types of sleep they induce.’
‘And what types are there?’

‘I put it wrong,’ Tim said, ‘the dream is always the same type — you fall asleep and you see it. But if you put on a moon mask, it’s like they’re telling you something, even though you see it too. It feels like a movie. And if you wear a Sun mask, everything happens to you personally. Sometimes the experience may seem too intense and even scary.’
‘When Frank told me about Caracalla, I literally saw what he was talking about…’
I was going to add that we lay side by side for a long time in these masks, but I refrained.
‘Try different options,’ Tim said.
Going to bed in the evening, I decided that it would be safer to put on a mask of the Moon. But the dream still started exactly where the last one ended.

p.emphasis: Emoji of a spectacular blonde who descended into the past so deeply that the future basement with ancient corpses is not visible from there, over which clickbait preachers on pink scooters snatch dildos from white niggas who dream of gender coming out in a thong with rhinestones or at least to pee on-budget behind a booth in a new russia.png

section.p: The shock was so strong that my memory did not come back to me immediately after returning from Hades. First thing I remembered was the name of the god I serve. And then my own name.
My name was Varius Avitus. My god’s name was Elagabal.
Under this name the Sun was worshipped in Emesa, and the temple of the Sun was the main attraction of the city. Our family has served Elagabal for many centuries.

My great-grandfather Julius Bassianus was a priest of the Sun and the father of Julia Domna, and she was the widow of Septimius Severus and the mother of the emperor, nicknamed Caracalla. After the death of her husband, it was my grandmother Domna who ruled a huge empire, while Caracalla was wandering around with his legions on its borders.
I rarely saw in Emesa my official father, a minor bureaucrat. He avoided this city, and women were mostly responsible for my upbringing.

As a kid, I traveled a lot with my elders. I have been to Rome several times. I remembered Britainia vaguely. Then Rome again, Nicomedia, and finally Emesa. Although I spent most of my life in Syria, because of my travels I considered myself a resident of the world.

From Rome I recalled only the city noise, a special Roman smell that is unlike anything else, and the statues of the Septicodium, the temple of the seven planets built by my grandfather Severus, remained in my memory. However, the word “temple” did not fit too well: the building was rather a narrow decoration, covering the ugly corners of nearby houses.

The false facade of the empire, my stepfather used to say, while he was taking me for a walk among trees and fountains. He was right — the Septicodium consisted of facade only. But I didn’t understand what the falsehood was. Fountains provided coolness, trees provided shade, Septicodium sparkled, it was beautiful, and what is truth if not beauty? If the truth is something else, who needs it then and for what purpose?
However, my fake dad had reasons not to like the truth.

I was the great-grandson of Julius Bassianus two times, from different directions, so to speak: through my grandmother Julia Maesa on my mother’s side, and through my grandmother Julia Domna on my real father’s side. Caracalla indulged in love games with a married cousin, as is customary among the gods and caesars, and from this divine relationship I was born.
At home, everyone knew that my parent was the emperor — my mother, without hesitation, boasted of this feat of debauchery and incest every time she happened to drink too much at dinner.
The emperor, meanwhile, was truly devoted to his family: another daughter of Maesa also had a son from Caracalla. He was two years younger than me and named Alexander.

Mother and aunt were so jealous of each other for the emperor, as if it was not about the sin, but about meeting Zeus, who took the form of an eagle. However, it was better not to joke about the topic of divine incest even for its participants.

Another childhood memory that has been etched into my memory: is Empress Julia Domna, the mother of Caracalla, receiving me and my mother in her boudoir. The same woman for whose insult the whole of Alexandria was punished.

I was too small to feel the immense distance between us. Therefore, I did not feel awe when looking at a fat naked old woman with an aquiline nose, sitting on a dais in the center of a round gilded room.

Her body was hidden up to her shoulders by a golden hoop with a curtain of colorful silk, so that we could only see her head and slightly flabby shoulders. But I was not even looking at her face, but at the amazing dance performed by the maids who put her hair in a hairstyle.

First, curly black strands (they were dyed before that) were divided into three parts. Then they pinned the side strands with thick bone needles and braided the back strand into a kind of wide and loose braid. And then they began to weave this back braid with side bunches, gathering everything together into a large chignon on the back of her head. At the same time, there was enough hair left on the sides of her face to frame it like a wavy helmet.

I especially liked how a tall dark-skinned maid, apparently from somewhere in our lands, wielded a bone needle, sewing the curls to each other. I didn’t know before that the hairstyles of noble ladies are sewn with a needle, like clothes.
The Empress herself, talking to her mother, did not pay attention to this procedure and gesticulated as if she was sitting next to her on a futon, and the maids skillfully evaded her flying palms.

‘The followers of the crucified god,’ Domna was saying in Greek, ‘are reshaping the story of Apollonius of Tyana. First in small pieces, and then in bigger and bigger… I ordered Flavius to collect what was known about Apollonius and write it down in beautiful words so that it would be harder for Christians to fool the people. My son, by the way, is now completing the temple dedicated to Apollonius, and I am so glad that he forgot about his soldiers at least for a while. However, even while exalting Apollonius, I will not speak ill of Christians. There is also a certain depth in their teaching. After all, God is one, my dear, and we just peek at him through different cracks and see Aphrodite, then Apollo…’
Domna’s speech flowed smoothly and softly, and its curly gloss resembled the black curls of her dyed hair.

I did not know then about Apollonius of Tyana, nor about Christ from Judea, and I understood only one thing: the word “my dear”, which constantly flies from the lips of the empress, lifted my mother and me to a sky-high height. I felt really proud.

Then Domna turned to me and asked me a question in Latin, to check how I knew the language. I answered correctly and cleanly, but not too respectfully. It was about the uniform of her personal praetorians standing guard. I didn’t approve of it. The Empress was very amused — no one had spoken to her like that for a long time.
Calling me over, she stroked my head (she had warm, trembling hands) and said:
‘He looks like his father. At his age he was the same wolf cub — and the same handsome one. The breed makes itself clear. This boy will go far, remember my words.’
‘How far, my Lady?’ the mother smiled.
‘As far as he can dance.’
The Empress drew a circle with her hand, as if showing the movement of the sun across the sky.
Everyone in our family understood this gesture. Domna, like my mother and I, belonged to the cult of the Sun, and exalting other gods, simply pitted them against each other.

When Septimius Severus learned of the prophecy that Domna’s husband would become a king, he made the most serious effort to win her hand. It turned out to be difficult: Severus was, in general, a lout and a soldier, and Julia was an educated and sophisticated Eastern beauty. But the marriage took place, and Severus became Emperor — either because of the prophecy, or because of his ambition, which forced him to marry Domna first, and then raise legions. The wise say, with prophecies it is always so.
No one in my childhood called me the son of the emperor, but even officially I was his relative. That’s why I grew up on a mountain, and not on a simple mountain, but on Olympus.

At least because most of the people around spoke Greek. This is the language of the emperors in general, it is not for nothing that the divine Marcus Aurelius wrote his philosophical notes in Greek (not that I would read them or was going to).

Marcus Aurelius was idolized in our family. Septimius Severus dreamed of resembling him as much as Caracalla dreamed of resembling the Macedonian King Alexander. But even Caracalla had to resemble Marcus — becoming a Princeps, he took his name. Half a century after Marcus’s death, his name became a kind of regalia inherited by the emperors.

The same, by the way, also applied to his everyday habits: people said, every second Eastern procurator now begins the day with a glass of opium mixed with wine, like a stoic philosopher. But after that Marcus resumed writing his book, but the procurators blissfully ponder what else to steal.
From my early childhood I was trained for the hereditary priesthood, and was taught the Dance.

God lived in a triangular black Stone that stood in the courtyard of the temple. I was taught to dance in front of him. It was believed that this Stone and the Sun in the sky are one, and many rhetoricians and sophists in Emesa were earning for life by explaining with impeccable logic how such a thing was possible.
The gods like it when beautiful boys and girls dance for them; looking at it, they become kinder to people. Everyone knew that. But the dance I learned was very special.

I was taught from infancy by an Egyptian named Gannys, a thin and very strong man without age or sex — although, from his shaved bald head it could be assumed that he was more of a man. However, in public he wore a long female wig.

He was a disciple of the Alexandrian mystics and a fugitive criminal, although no one really knew what his crime was. There was a serious reward for his head, and even the high position of our family could not help him, so in the days of my childhood he posed as a eunuch and diligently painted his face.

I must admit that it was from him that I picked up this habit. Gannys had a reason to wear makeup — he didn’t want to be recognized accidentally. My only reason to do so was admiration for the mentor, whom I sought to emulate in everything. Gannys was wise and kind.

He guessed that I was not only inspired, but also embarrassed by my double relationship with my great-grandfather, revered in Emesa as a priest of Elagabal. Therefore, he showed me ancient Egyptian figurines and statuettes, a great many of which he kept in his chambers: carved with wonderful skill, they depicted cheerful men and women with their skulls stretched back. The women were very beautiful. Their pear-shaped skulls still have pink-brown paint.

Gannys said, this was the family of an Egyptian king who served the Sun many centuries ago, and their heads had such a shape because of, as he delicately put it, ‘in-family marriages.’ Although Gannys did not directly say that incest and worshipping the Sun were somehow connected, it seemed to be implied; I understood his desire to comfort me in what many considered a disgrace, and I was grateful.

‘This king,’ said Gannys, ‘lived a long time ago. At that time there was neither Rome, nor even Athens. He glorified the Sun, and it taught his kind the heavenly language. This is not the language of words, Varius, but the language of Dance. The language of the heart that expresses itself through body movements. Do you understand what this is?’
‘Not really, Teacher,’ I replied, squinting out the window.
I wanted, of course, to go free.

‘A person knows how to talk to other people. But you can’t talk to god like that. God will not understand our words. Rather, he won’t be listening to them, because they reflect a poor and erroneous human understanding. However, the movements of the heart that arise before the words are understandable to the gods. God does not hear you when you say the words “anger”, “love”, “joy”. But he sees you if you are overcome with anger or joy. And he sees you best when you feel love…’
‘What is love, Teacher?’ I asked.
‘You know where children are born from?’
‘Yes,’ I said, ‘I know. I even know what they won’t be born from.’
‘I suppose,’ Gannys smiled, ‘it’s hard to grow up in your house and not know it in all the slightest details.’
‘And what, is god watching? Is he interested?’
‘That’s not what I’m talking about,’ Gannys said, ‘There is an external expression of love that you have thought of. In fact, it does not even need love and can perfectly exist without it.’
‘I know that, too,’ I confirmed.

‘But there is real love — a feeling that arises in the heart and subordinates the mind. Because of it, people are doing what we talked about, and much, much more. Moreover, even the gods tolerate our world because of love. But this is an unhappy love.’
‘Why?’
‘Because the world is unhappy,’ Gannys replied. ‘If the world is unhappy, how can the power that loves it be happy?’

It seemed easy to me at the time. I could, for example, pour water on an anthill to watch the tiny brown soldiers scatter, and I was quite happy at the same time. I imagined that I was an ant god and was destroying their main city with a flood. But I never once wondered what the ants imagined at the same time.

It turns out that being a god meant not enjoying games, but, on the contrary, being sad? But then why pour water on the anthill at all? And the gods pour it all the time. Or do some gods pour, and others grieve?
‘So the gods are unhappy?’ I asked.

‘I wasn’t a god,’ Gannys replied. ‘But I have heard from the wise that for the gods’ happiness and unhappiness are like a game. They are getting drunk by them, as people are intoxicated by wine and opium.’
‘How can you get drunk with unhappiness?’
‘It is difficult for us to understand how this can be…’
Gannys got up and adjusted the wick of the lamp burning on the wall. There was no particular need for this, but he often did it when he wanted to separate one part of the conversation from another.
‘Let me get back to the dance,’ he said. ‘You will be able to speak to the gods in their language only when your dance will generate clear feelings in them.’
‘In whom? The gods?’
‘First in yourself,’ answered Gannys, ‘Then in other people. And through this in the gods.’
‘How?’
‘You are, and the others — are just cracks through which the gods look into our world. You have to learn to behave in such a way that the gods will notice you…’
‘But can I do so?’
‘I hope so. Feelings are your new words.’
‘But how can you speak with feelings? You can say anything, truth or lies. And feelings… What they are, they really are. Is it possible to change them according to your choice?’

‘Your name is Varius,’ Gannys replied. ‘That is, “different”. This is the sign that the gods marked you with. Changing is your destiny. You’ve studied body dance and you’re good at it, but now it’s time to step up a notch.’
He went to the door and called someone from the corridor.

A flute player from Bithynia entered. He often played to my mother before going to bed, when he was alone with her, but she was not afraid of rumors, because he was old, lame and extremely ugly. However, he played excellently and knew many barbaric melodies.
‘Play Varius,’ Gannys said.
It sounded strange, but I guessed that he was asking the flutist to play a melody similar to me. He started playing something fun, light, and rather uncomplicated.
‘You can play yourself and dance yourself,’ Gannys said. ‘However, I’m not asking you to dance yourself, you already do that every day. I’ll give you the task which is more complicated…’
He turned to the flutist.
‘Play yourself.’

The flutist smiled, thought for a while, and played something quiet and mournful: such a dreary melody that it resembled the creak of a cart wheel. Indeed, it was like him — I could feel his old bones aching on a damp morning…
‘Can you dance this old man, Varius?’

It seemed to me at first that the task was simple. I walked around the room, dragging my leg and generally moving as if it hurt me to walk. The flutist moved in this way. My pantomime was very accurate, but Gannys shook his head in displeasure.
‘You’re not dancing him. You’re dancing yourself impersonating an old man. And you need to dance the old man.’
I tried again, limping harder, and wincing like an old slave did.

‘No,’ Gannys said. ‘Not at all. Your dance is full of strength and joy, and shows only how youth despises the old. You’re portraying him from the outside. Try to see it from the inside. Get yourself out of the dance. Let the music dance…’

I understood what he wanted to say. What does it feel like to be an old man who is so ugly that noble women are not afraid of bad rumors, staying alone with him all night? I couldn’t imagine it, but I heard the sound of a flute. I moved forward uncertainly…
‘Don’t think about anything,’ Gannys said. ‘Dance… Here, here. It already looks like it. Good. Just great!’

I wasn’t thinking about anything, really. I suddenly became as old and unhappy as the melody that scratched my ear. I didn’t have to pretend anything — the music did everything, passing through my ears and moving my arms and legs… Even my face was twisted in such a way, as if I had pinched a few flies in the wrinkles around my eyes and was now afraid to let them out…
The flutist stopped playing. It seemed to me that hatred flashed in his eyes.
Gannys laughed and patted the musician on the back.
‘That’s enough, you may go.’
When the old man came out, Gannys said,
‘You did it. But dancing another person is not so difficult. It is much more difficult to dance a river. Or a mountain. Or a cloud.’
‘I need someone to play them,’ I replied.

‘That’s the problem. Musicians for the most part are not capable of such a thing. You will have to find the required twists and cracks in the usual dance music yourself. And that’s probably the hardest part…’

That’s what he said — “twists and cracks.” I could still understand the word “twists” — these, for example, were the changing directions of the melody: the music is always going somewhere, or even jumping. But what are the cracks in it?
I asked Gannys.
‘Julius Bassianus could’ve explained that,’ he replied. ‘And if I’m lucky, you’ll explain it to me.’
‘I’ll learn to see cracks in music,’ I said, ‘and then my leg will get there and break, and I’ll limp all my life. They say my great-grandfather limped.’
‘He knew the ancient art coming from the kings of Egypt. Dance of the Sun God…’

Since childhood, I have heard adults arguing about the magical dance of Julius, and although I understood almost all the words and even recognized some sophistic techniques (after all, the best rhetoricians and philosophers taught me), the essence of these disputes was not too clear to me.

It was said about my great-grandfather, the priest, that he was behind the rise of our family, because he was the seer, who predicted the marriage of Julia’s daughter with the future king. The meaning of the prediction was that marriage would make the groom the king.

Following my great-grandfather, the prophecy was repeated by several other famous soothsayers. The soothsayers did not lie and did not participate in collusion. They really began to see in the future what Julius Bassian saw, just after he saw it.

But there was one detail that completely changed the whole story. Initiated into the cult of the Sun in Emesa told in secret that Julius did not just predict this event, but danced it. Although how such a complex idea could be put into body movements, I did not understand even after the exercises with Gannys.

It seemed to me that the dance should depict the king, then marriage. Such a thing lent itself to mimicking art. But it also had to be shown that the royal future of the groom awaited him for a reason, and was the result of a wisely concluded marriage union… And this, in my opinion, was absolutely inexpressible without words.

However, there were two old slaves still alive, who had seen this dance of Julius Bassianus as boys, and I questioned them several times. They said that the dance did not last long and was not very expressive. Julius walked with a plastic gait in front of the Sun Stone and stretched his arms up, sometimes laughing, sometimes crying.

I asked him to show me exactly how he stretched out his arms. Then one of the slaves made a strange movement — as if he took his head off his shoulders and held it out to the sky, like a bowl made of a skull.
‘This way many times,’ he said. ‘I remember I was thinking that he wants another head and asks the god of the mountain about it.’
The slave spoke Greek very poorly, but still tried to translate the name of Elagabal into a foreign language. I did not punish him: if god is offended, let him stand up for himself.
There was another story that this slave told in secret about if he was treated with wine or given a couple of coins.
Julius Bassianus danced the death of Commodus, who was emperor in Rome in his days.

This dance was different — Julius sang something and danced on the spot, sometimes switching to high jumps up (the slave showed how). At the same time, he made small and not too beautiful movements with his hands near his chest, as if adjusting a neckerchief.

And soon after this dance, news came from the West that a gladiator Narcissus, who trained the emperor in circus wrestling (and, as they added, was in a much closer relationship with him than gymnastic) strangled him during exercises.
Julius Bassianus was a Soltator — that’s what they called it in our family. We believed that he could talk to the gods through his dance when the spirit of the Sun descends on him.
‘Soltator is like a god dancing in front of a mirror,’ said Gannys. ‘A dancing man becomes a god for a while. Such were the ancient kings of Egypt. And especially the queens.’
‘Does god obey?’

‘It’s not about obedience. God sees a dancing man and takes him for his reflection. The desire of god and the desire of man must coincide. This is a very mysterious event. God cannot be commanded. But you can become one, and as if you explain to god what he really wants. Through this gap, Varius, Soltator can control the whole world.’
‘And what does god want?’
‘Dancing,’ Gannys smiled. ‘But his dance is not what you were taught. The whole world is his dance.’
‘How can the world be a dance?’
‘You’re too young to understand such things.’
‘Tell me, Teacher. Maybe I’ll understand after all.’
Gannys closed his eyes and immediately looked like one of the ancient granite statues that stood in the courtyard of our house.
‘Have you seen how jugglers twist ropes with burning tow balls around themselves during the holidays?’
‘Of course,’ I said, ‘I can do it well myself.’
‘When they do it quickly, the light begins to describe different shapes — you see circles, ellipses, spirals, and so on.’
‘Yes,’ I agreed.

‘In fact, there is only a small bright light. But it dances so fast that the illusion of a circle or spiral appears before your eyes. God is a very small and very bright light, a kind of firefly that flies much faster than any lump of burning tow on a rope. God does it so fast that the illusion of the whole world appears before your eyes.’
‘So the world is an illusion?’ I asked.

‘I’m not a philosopher,’ Gannys said. ‘Illusion is just a word. One of those words that philosophers use. They, my dear boy, call the world this way, or that way — but nothing changes. A philosopher can at best earn a bowl of beans with his wisdom. But everything changes from what Soltator does, and in the most noticeable way. A metamorphosis is taking place with the world. That’s the difference.’
‘Julius Bassianus could change the world as he wanted?’
‘Soltator does not set himself the goal of changing the world according to his understanding,’ said Gannys. ‘He fulfills the will of god. Rather, it helps god to understand what it is.’
‘How can this be,’ I whispered contritely, ‘because you need to understand god better than he himself…’
Gannys smiled.

‘The secret is that god doesn’t really want anything at all. In any case, from our world. Imagine that you are lying at a feast without any desires. And then a servant passes by, carrying, let’s say… What did you eat today?’
‘Garum,’ I said.
‘A dish with garum. And you, who didn’t know what you wanted a minute ago, shout across the hall — hey, bring here the fish sauce! Over here!’
I laughed. The example was clear, and really reminded me of my behavior during meals.
‘However, it’s not that simple,’ Gannys continued, ‘You know how many different things are served in your house at dinner.’
I nodded.
‘The same thing happens with god, to whom people offer many different dishes. Your art is to make god notice you of all people…’
‘But how?’

‘You will explain this to me, not I to you. Julius Bassianus expressed it like this: it’s difficult if you say it, and easy when you do it. The heart should be calm and the spirit should be clear. God keeps the balance, Varius.’
‘The balance of what?’
‘For example, the balance of external and internal. And in general all things with each other. Help him.’
‘How?’
‘Come to balance yourself. In order for what you want to happen, the first thing you have to do is stop wanting.’
‘How can you stop wanting if you want to?’
‘Soltator doesn’t want anything at all,’ Gannys replied, ‘because he knows what the world is. When this is comprehended, it is impossible to want something as before.’
‘But why strive for what you no longer want?’
‘Soltator doesn’t want to,’ Gannys said. ‘Therefore, the desired ceases to be desired and becomes proper. And when it becomes proper, it happens.’
‘I don’t understand.’
‘Don’t try to understand it. Just dance.’
‘But I want to understand,’ I said.
‘Then dance that, too.’
Imperial Roman mile is estimated to have been around 1481 meters, or 1620 yards.
“Bella Ciao” originally is an Italian protest folk song from the late 19th century, which later was modified and adopted as an anthem of the Italian Resistance movement during WWII.
Pedophrasty is the use of emotionally charged children’s images to promote commercial and political agendas.
